March 6, 1950.

Dear Col. Neary:

You will have received, recently, a copy of my Circular #15—The Reading Programme—Curriculum I.

May I add that, at my request to the publishers, Father Oliver, Spanish, has received a complimentary set of each of the titles indicated in my circular—Gr. 1-6, for examination and assessment by the staffs of both Spanish Indian Schools.

It seems probable that the Spanish staffs could advise you first-hand, as to the suitability of the several series referred to, and the fairly rich programme, advocated in my circular.

May I add that it is my opinion that, in Indian Schools, facilitating learning to read, is even more imperative than in most other schools.

Yours sincerely,

Wm. H. Bulger,
Inspector.

Col. B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sirs:

Attached you will find schedules issued by the Northern Transportation Company, Edmonton in reference to shipments from Waterways, Alberta to the localities in the North.

As in former years, we are prepared to accept shipments to the Northern schools at 220 Queen Street. When navigation opens we will arrange to forward them on to Waterways, Alberta.

School Supplies - Indian Schools

Dear Mr. Query:

For the past month your Mr. Joly of the Book Unit and our Mr. Trask in charge of requisitions for school supplies, have been meeting to work out a system which will be taken into use when your new International Business Machines equipment is put into operation from April 1, 1950.

You will recall our conversations of a year ago and will remember that I promised to advise you concerning the relative efficiency of the new system as compared with the old. I believe that we can now report to you that the establishment of this Book Unit has been a wise move and one which has proven beneficial to us. Since the establishment of this Book Unit we have had few complaints from our school inspectors, principals and teachers.

We are also pleased to report that Mr. Joly has proven to be obliging and cooperative in his dealings with this office. He has shown a genuine interest in our educational problems and has done his best to help when difficult cases have arisen.

Our two officials have worked out a priority system which is very effective and it is hoped that this can be
incorporated in the new machine system operation as this feature is due to the relative isolation of some of our schools and the inevitable delays which occur in receiving their requisitions.

You can expect an increase during June, July and August of the number of requisitions sent to the Book Unit from this Division. Our school building programme is naturally aimed at building new schools by September the first. These have to be completely stocked and added to our normal increase in requisitions during the summer months leads to a heavy demand for supplies.

It is necessary for us to employ during these months two university students to assist in the extra flow of work here. As I have previously mentioned to you, some consideration could be given to hiring university students also in the Book Unit. I believe that requisitions are now being filled within about four weeks. With the closing of the Unit during the installation of the new machines, this will increase the delay to about two months. If we are to give efficient service to our schools, this delay gap must be reduced before the end of June.

In conclusion may I express my appreciation to you and to your staff for the understanding and cooperation which we have received in the meeting of our mutual problem.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

This Department does not conduct summer schools at which qualified teachers may receive credit towards a higher grade of license. Teachers wishing to advance their grade of license usually attend summer school sessions at some Maritime university.

Since 1947, however, we have conducted a summer school to enable permit teachers to qualify for regular license. A permit teacher with a Grade XI standing may obtain a Second Class License on the successful completion of two summer sessions and a professional reading course taken by correspondence during the school year. You are aware that in the next three months we must furnish our Indian schools across the country with sufficient school supplies and textbooks for opening of school on the 5th of September.

It has been brought to my attention that quite a number of items are not being shipped at present mainly due to two reasons: (1) items not in stock due to one reason or another and (2) items are in stock but a billing has not been received from the suppliers consequently the articles cannot be released for shipment until the cost price has been secured.

As it is, the shipments are held up at present resulting in additional work for your shipping staff and complaints from the schools.

Your usual co-operation in having this matter rectified would be appreciated. It is also hoped that additional shipping staff will be engaged at 47 Clarence Street for the summer months to clear up the large back log of requisitions by September.

Dear Colonel Neary,

I am sending you the first draft of Mr. Woodley's manuscript "The Indian in Canada's Story," which, of course, has a poor title and will have to be changed to something more lively.

I have not read the manuscript, as I wanted you to have it right away, but I notice that Mr. Woodley's treatment is predominantly a historical one, the theme being exactly what its title implies.

The contents looks good, although he wants to add one or two other subjects in section 4 dealing with Indian achievement. I think your Department could help him in this matter, as he wants something about Indian Crafts, and I assume also something about present-day activities of Indians would be acceptable.

He has included some seat work which could be either retained in the book or left out.

Personally, I think that the book should be illustrated by an artist.

As far as I can tell from a cursory examination the material is simply written, but I do get the impression that it is presented from the point of view of a non-Indian. In other words, it is a book that tells the non-Indian about the Indian. This may sound a little obscure, but I had in mind a book that would tell the Indians about themselves.

This point of view could, however, be easily altered by editing. You may want one of your own teachers to go over this, as I think it will need a little simplifying here and there where Mr. Woodley's knowledge of history may take for granted knowledge that the youngster of this grade level does not have.

I hope you will try to visualize the book with illustrations and diagrams. I am sure that it can be made into a useful supplementary book.

Yours sincerely,

C. J. Eustace

Although the book is not large, it has involved a great deal of reading. Often considerable reading only resulted in the discovery of a stray fact or item which I could use. I do not know of any book which gives such a general view of the place of the Indian in Canada's story, hence my title.

I have given the attached books a considerable amount of study and believe they could prove quite useful to our uncertified teachers and teachers who are behind in the latest teaching methods.

The reading course opens with "We Work and Play" reader and goes on to "Fun with Dick and Jane" and "Our New Friends". The "Before We Read" is discarded entirely. "We Look and See" is reviewed. "We Come and Go" is recommended for extra reading work so is "We Look and See". These all make reading difficult for the Indian children to follow as they do not have the background that children for whom this series was prepared. The author of the readers states that "We Work and Play" may be used as the initial Pre-Primer for average and superior pupils who are well prepared for reading, since it provides for the basic development of all words including the seventeen introduced in "We Look and See".

The teacher, by using the Teachers Manual, the workbooks provided and the readers can make a success of her reading program. The 100 types of Primary Seatwork which we supply will prove useful. I feel that the Correspondence Course would prove helpful too, however, not essential.

The Arithmetic as handled in the course is quite good. However, the use of Jolly Numbers, the Jolly Numbers Manual, the Provincial Course of Study and 100 Types of Primary Seatwork should accomplish equal results.
As we have not settled on a suitable Printing and Writing book for use in the schools, this course has some useful suggestions that might be worthy of consideration.

The Social Studies as handled is not new, as a teacher can pick up a library book and read a suitable story, or tell a story on a subject she wants to put across and provides seatwork from suggestions in 100 types of Primary Seatwork and the Curriculum.

Summing up this Correspondence Course deals particularly with reading and as its beginning is too advanced for our schools the whole set is out of line. The stories for Social Studies are quite difficult for our children. The seatwork is outstanding, however, as all books go, this course has some very fine points. The Christmas Program is very well done.

On the attached letter it is indicated that the cost is $2.00 each. Does that mean $8.00 for the four books, which would be very cheap as the paper and ink alone will cost more than that. On the other hand, the cost may be $2.00 a book, which will make it $8.00 a set.

Personally, I would be afraid to place these courses in our schools, as the teachers might be inclined to follow it too rigidly and discourage the children or decide that they are not suited and place them in a corner to accumulate dust.

M.F. Track

The International Labour Office, with headquarters at Geneva, Switzerland, has produced a considerable literature in the fields of labour and social topics since its foundation in 1919.

Apart from general topics, such as trends in labour and social legislation and administration, many ILO books are technical studies or treatises on the various phases of Industrial Accident Prevention, Occupational Medicine, Industrial Relations, Social Security, Unemployment, Conditions of Employment, Vocational Training, and other like subjects.

A partial list of periodical publications and of recently issued books is here given. These may be secured from Canada Branch, ILO, 95 Rideau Street, OTTAWA.

General Periodical Publications

International Labour Review (Monthly). Articles on economic and social topics; statistics on employment, wages, cost of living, etc. Price: paper, $2.00 per copy; 50 cents per month; per year, $5.00.

Industry and Labour (Issued twice a month). Information concerning the activities of the ILO and developments in the field of industrial relations, employment, migration, conditions of work, social security and the activities of employers' and workers' organisations. Price: per single copy, 50 cents; per month, $1.00.

Legislative Series (Issued in instalments every two months). Reprints and translations of labour and social laws and regulations in various countries. Annual subscription: $7.50.

International Labour Statistics

Year Book of Labour Statistics. Employment, hours of work, wages, prices, migration, etc. (Recently issued edition is for 1947-1948). Price: paper, $4.00; cloth, $5.00.

Industrial Safety

Industrial Safety Survey (published every two months). Deals with problems of industrial accident prevention. Price, $2.50 per year.

Safety in Factories. Description of the Institutions, Laws and Regulations relating to safety in leading countries (including Canada). (This is a volume of about 1,700 pages.) Price, $8.50.

Model Code of Safety Regulations for Industrial Establishments for the Guidance of Governments and Industry. An attempt of more than 500 pages compiled after years of research under the guidance of the ILO's International Committee on Industrial Safety. Price, $4.00.

Occupational Medicine

Bibliography of Occupational Medicine, Vol. I, 1948. This volume contains a complete ILO series interrupted by the War, and gives a list of publications issued in various countries on occupational medicine, industrial disease and related subjects. It is now completed and will be issued in November, 1949. Price, $1.00 each.

Bibliography of Occupational Medicine (Issued quarterly, starting in 1950). This follows up on Vol. I and Vol. II, issued with the same object and keeps up to date the list of publications from various countries on occupational medicine and industrial diseases. Price, per year, $1.00.

Social Security in Various Countries

Systems of Social Security — New Zealand. Price: $0.40.

It is planned to publish a series of booklets describing systems of social security in various member countries. The first report, now available, deals with New Zealand.

International Labour Legislation

Conventions and Recommendations, 1919-1949. Gives authentic texts of all International Labour Conventions and Recommendations adopted by the International Labour Conferences up to 1949. Price: $5.00.

ILO Activities

Documents of the International Labour Conference. The Director-General's reports, technical reports prepared for the information of the Conference, final record, and texts of Conventions and Recommendations. Annual subscription: $10.00.

Reports of the Triennial Labour Organization to the United Nations. A statistical summary (usually yearly) of the work of the Organisation. At varying prices.

Official Bulletin (issued irregularly). Official documents and information concerning the International Labour Organisation, including the texts adopted by the Conference and other meetings. Issued yearly.

Minutes of Meetings of the ILO Governing Body: and also documents of ILO Committee Meetings and special conferences, on technical subjects. At varying prices.

Technical Reports

Studies and Reports on Economic and Social subjects. These are issued from time to time dealing with various technical subjects. As an indication of the following are among those which have been published since the close of the War:

World Economic Development (1945): $1.75.

Training and Employment of Disabled Persons (1945): $1.50.

Nutrition in Industry (1946): $1.50.

Methods of Statistics of Industrial Injuries (1947): $0.25.

Employment, Unemployment & Labour Force Statistics (1948): $0.75.

Housing and Employment (1949): $0.75.

International Standard Classification of Occupations (1949): $0.75.

Development of the Co-operative Movement in Asia (1949): $0.75.

Action Against Unemployment (1950): $1.50.

Collection of Texts of international social or economic importance.

Technical Papers and Pamphlets on current social and economic problems, legislation and administrative practice. At varying prices.

In Preparation

Works now in preparation include:

Occupation and Health. Encyclopaedia of Industrial Hygiene.

The International Labour Code. A systematic arrangement of the Conventions and Recommendations adopted by the International Labour Conference with appendices and notes.

Model Code of Safety for Underground Work in Coal Mines. This is the result of ILO research and also includes the meetings on the subject. Probably available about August, 1950.

Orders for any publications of the International Labour Office should be addressed to the Canada Branch, ILO, 95 Rideau Street, OTTAWA. All prices quoted above include postage.

Correspondence is invited from those interested in any ILO publications. A limited number of the periodical publications are available as samples on request. Catalogues are available for the use of libraries.

The membership of the Organisation consists of 60 Governments (including Canada). In the councils of the Organisation, direct representation is given not only to member Governments, but also to the Employer Groups and Trade Unions of member-countries. Under an agreement, the Organisation is one of the Specialized Agencies of the United Nations.

During the past two years this Branch of the Dept. was in a state of confusion from March to the middle of October with the appointment of teachers for Indian day schools, and due to the fact that more and more teachers were applying for Indian schools, great care had to be exercised to pick out the most suitable candidates from a large number of applicants. It was decided that a system would have to be devised to cope with the work. A system that would be easy to handle yet efficient was required.

The Department requested the Civil Service Commission to send in an efficiency expert to study the problem and install a suitable set-up. Mr. T.J. Brook and Mr. V.J. Layton, Organization and Methods Division of the Civil Service Commission spent considerable time during April and May surveying the Division paying particular attention to the appointing of Indian day school teachers. After the survey was completed these experts decided on a system that would serve our purpose.

To put the new system into operation as effectively as possible it was necessary to have the exact type of material and additional staff, as it was essential to make the change over at once in order to have it completed before the peak load in June, July and August.

Mr. Brook had had dealings with John C. Preston previously and purchased the required materials from this firm. The Civil Service Commission appointed two additional clerks for a period of two months to carry out the change over. As the change over continued under Mr. Brook's and Mr. Layton's supervision it was found that additional materials were required which they purchased as they went along.

In view of the above, it would be appreciated if these two accounts (one for $176.01 and the other for $154.21) were put through for payment. Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY

Mr. Bernard McEvoy, Assistant Manager of Longmans, Green and Company was in Ottawa and came to the office to see you. However, as you were out of town at the time, I saw him and he mentioned to me about the manuscript on "The Indians of Canada". He stated that he had spoken to you two years ago and that you would review it for him.

I have read the manuscript from cover to cover and find it quite interesting. I particularly liked the last section dealing with the Iroquois. For some reason or another the first two sections are most uninteresting to the reader but the third and last section is very well done. It is not the information that makes the reading dull, it is the style. There appears to be considerable difference in the style between the first two sections and the third.

I think the manuscript requires more folk stories, yarns or anything to give spice to the thing.

The writer unfortunately follows the old pattern of writing a history book. He starts from the long time ago and comes in to Canadian History and stops there.
I would think he should commence his book with Indians of today and work on arousing the reader's interest in Indians, their habits, religion, livelihood, what the Indian has contributed to the White man, what the White man has contributed to the Indian, where Indians live today, what they are doing, how the Indians have changed from the Indians of the past, where is the athletic and muscular Indian of the past, etc., anything to arouse interest.

The writer of the book is determined to write a history book and he proceeds to do just that, by means of simple assertive sentences. This does not provide the necessary interest to the reader.

I think the book is quite well done and it appears to have covered considerable subject matter. However, more would be required. The style needs improvement. The Indians of today should be brought into the picture and their contributions should be appreciated.

M.F. Track.

July 24, 1950.

Dear Sir:

It has been brought to my attention that you have purchased and placed in stock a large quantity of poster paper and folding paper.

This paper is in pastel colors of a very poor quality and is lacking in sufficient variety of colors to be of interest to the children and teachers using it. It is possible that this paper might have been a few cents cheaper than the conventional paper; however, it is felt that the saving is very small and irrelevant for we supply only a packet or two to a school.

The poster paper and folding paper that is considered suitable should be equal to the product supplied by Hendry Division Central Scientific Company Limited.

As the purchase has been made and the paper supplied and placed in stock, the Department is prepared to accept it. However, no further orders should be placed for this product. We feel that the Department will be receiving a great number of complaints from the teachers, principals and school inspectors on the matter to say the least.

It would be appreciated and it would save you considerable difficulty if arrangements could be made whereby when quotations and tenders are secured for requirements for school use that the samples and quotations be forwarded to this office for a recommendation or this office be consulted before a tender is accepted.
In this way it is felt that embarrassments could be avoided and savings made at the same time.

I would like to hear your views on the matter. You can appreciate the fact that school supplies are of a special category and require the attention of persons closely connected with the people using these supplies.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Doucet:

A note from our Alberta representative, Miss Jessie E. Casselman, mentions that she had the pleasure of meeting you in Edmonton in June, while you were there on Indian affairs business. She asked that we send a copy of our catalog, which was mailed on July 12, and we hope that it may have reached you by this time. If it has not been received, by all means let us know.

We have had the pleasure of working with the Education Department of the Office of Indian Affairs here at home over a period of many years, and Mr. W. W. Beatty who is in charge of the work, is well known to us. Probably you have come in contact with him in the discussion of various problems. As you may know, the Department of Education, Office of Indian Affairs, has developed a list of approved or recommended items for the Indian schools here in this country. If you do not have a copy of this list we would be glad to send you one giving the Denoyer-Geppert items that are approved and recommended for use in the Indian schools.

We do not know whether you have such a list of approved items for the Canadian Indian schools. If you do have such a list, we would like to offer our materials for approval. We sincerely believe that you would find they would give the same satisfactory service that they are regularly providing in the schools of many of your large cities from coast to coast.

In addition to our catalogs, we have been glad to distribute an envelope containing a number of leaflets on map and globe use, as a service to teachers. We are sending one of these envelopes to you. If you think it would be helpful, and you would like copies sent to key members of your staff in various parts of Canada, just let us know, and we will be glad to send them as required, without obligation or expense of any kind.

Above all, Mr. Doucet, we want you to feel that we are sincerely interested in working with you in your program, and will be glad to do everything that we can to help with it.

Dear Sirs:

Attention Mr. E. F. Neary
Re: File No. 1-1-4 (E6)

We thank you very much for your inquiry of the 21st instant asking for prices and information on a Steel Storage Cabinet which you intend to use in your schools across the country.

We are very pleased to get an inquiry such as this because we operate a plant that is able to design and produce custom built equipment to any specifications. We are going to have our Drafting Department make up a rough sketch of our proposals but before doing so it would be necessary to get some further information.

1. Are these cabinets to sit on the floor with a toe-hole or are they to be put on legs? If they are to go on legs, kindly advise the height they should be from the ground.

2. You do not mention whether there should be any doors on this cabinet and we would appreciate clarification regarding this point. We would also be interested to know if the door should have any sort of a lock on it.

3. Before giving you an estimate it would also be necessary to know the quantity you would be prepared to order for shipment at one time.

When this information comes to hand we will then be in a position to submit a sketch along with complete specifications, prices and delivery date.

Cont'd.
Again thanking you for this inquiry and trusting to have your prompt reply, we are,

Yours very truly,
CANADIAN ROGERS WESTERN LIMITED,

Dear Colonel Neary:

We are mailing you today a copy of CHEZ NOUS. This, as you shall see, is the French version of THIS IS OUR HOME, the basic pre-primer in the FAITH AND FREEDOM reading series. CHEZ NOUS has just come from the press and I hastened to get a copy for you since Mr. Robinson of this office requested that you receive it promptly. Robbie is presently in Ottawa and, no doubt, will be seeing you.

You will find that all the excellent features of THIS IS OUR HOME have been maintained in CHEZ NOUS, even vocabulary control. If anything, I think you will agree with us that the French version seems to be even more lively than its English counterpart.

CHEZ NOUS has been approved by the Minister of Education for basal use in the Province of Ontario and the book is off to a good start in the bilingual schools here. We shall be glad to provide you with any additional information you may require regarding this French edition.

Incidentally, the primer, THIS IS OUR FAMILY, will be coming from the press within a few weeks under the title NOTRE FAMILLE.

Dear Sir:

Thank you for your letter 1-1-4 (E6) of September 1st, we have much pleasure in quoting prices on all lines of Equipment.

We are sending you the complete line of Aluminum Alloy furniture pictures, as manufactured by the Educational Supply Association of London, England, this light, almost unbreakable equipment is going over extremely well with the School Boards of B.C., the Department in Victoria have seen it, and really think as we do, that it is the answer to all School furniture problems, it is light, durable, cast in one piece, all chairs and the Primary table have the added feature of stacking.

The Educational Supply Association as you are probably aware, have been manufacturing School furniture for 70 years, this line is the most commonly used in the Old Country now, and is also being extensively purchased in the U.S.A. which speaks for itself, no one in their wildest dreams ever expected America to buy British School furniture.

We have shown it to members of your Department here, but they were afraid of the price, however here is something to last a lifetime. We are in a raising market in hardwood which brings this equipment more and more in line.

If you can get away from the import duty on this equipment, and we are not sure of that, it would be very much cheaper, however the Government would be only taking it out of one pocket and placing it in another.

As far as wooden equipment is concerned we are in a position to supply everything, and would greatly appreciate being allowed to quote on your needs.

Enclosed are price lists of most lines, Sales Tax is included, and we find by shipping pool car that Edmonton and Calgary have the same rate from here.

MEMORANDUM:

Col. Neary

I am very pleased to have had the opportunity of reading the manuscript written by Mr. Kidd, and it appears to me that it is, if anything, superior to the previous manuscript submitted. Certainly anyone who read this manuscript would acquire a great deal of knowledge about the Indians of this country.

However, I do not think it would hold the attention of the juvenile reader as there is far too much detail in it and little, if any, action.
Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY

Mr. Bernard McEvoy, Assistant Manager of Longmans, Green and Company, was in Ottawa and came to the office to see you. However, as you were out of town at the time, I saw him and he mentioned to me about the manuscript on "The Indians of Canada". He stated that he had spoken to you two years ago and that you would review it for him.

I have read the manuscript from cover to cover and find it quite interesting. I particularly liked the last section dealing with the Iroquois. For some reason or another the first two sections are most uninteresting to the reader but the third and last section is very well done. It is not the information that makes the reading dull, it is the style. There appears to be considerable difference in the style between the first two sections and the third.

I think the manuscript requires more folk stories, yarns or anything to give spice to the thing.

The writer unfortunately follows the old pattern of writing a history book. He starts from the long time ago and comes in to Canadian History and stops there.
I would think he should commence his book with Indians of today and work on arousing the reader's interest in Indians, their habits, religion, livelihood, what the Indian has contributed to the White man, what the White man has contributed to the Indian, where Indians live today, what they are doing, how the Indians have changed from the Indians of the past, where is the athletic and muscular Indian of the past, etc., anything to arouse interest.

The writer of the book is determined to write a history book and he proceeds to do just that, by means of simple assertive sentences. This does not provide the necessary interest to the reader.

I think the book is quite well done and it appears to have covered considerable subject matter. However, more would be required. The style needs improvement. The Indians of today should be brought into the picture and their contributions should be appreciated.

M.F. Track.

The Indian in Canada by E.C. Woodley

I have just completed reading the above-noted manuscript and cannot be too sure as to the purpose it can be put to, if any, in our schools.

The material included is far from complete as there are enormous possibilities for covering more subjects such as culture, mode of living, religion, contributions to the White man, etc. Many of the subjects are covered but not as fully as required for school children, as not only facts are required, but these have to be elaborated to make the reading both interesting and educational.

The style is most unsuitable for school children. Mr. Woodley treats the subject matter as if he were writing a Chemistry book or Arithmetic book for he is stating facts after facts. To make a history book readable and valuable one must introduce short stories, incidents, comparisons, etc. A history book ought to be written like a novel rather than an assembly of facts.

I am attaching a list of notes picked up from time to time while reading the manuscript.

COL. NEARY

I have read this manuscript with great interest. It would appear to me that the writer has done considerable research but has attempted the impossible, i.e. to cover the entire history of a race, including the biography of a group of outstanding men and women, in less than 35,000 words.

In order to do this he has obviously condensed his material and denuded it of the colour and fire necessary in a "juvenile".

Just how much this is responsible for the style, i.e. long, confusing sentences, I would hesitate to say. In any event the result is deadly.

Should the author attempt to rewrite, with a view to meeting requirements of the age group it is designed for, here are a few minor observations.

The use of the word "ward" is noted. Legally the Indian is not a ward of the Crown. Similarly we do not use "reservation" but, in Canada, it is "reserve".

Page 17. "General Baden-Powell" should be "Lord Baden-Powell". Also the Boy Scout material is not accurate.

Page 19. The section on hunting and fishing is a good spot to work in something on conservation.

Page 54. The chapter on Paul Kane adds little to the book.

Page 82. Joseph Brant.
"The war in America dragged on until 1782, and Joseph Brant and the Mohawks took their part in it to the very end, but when the Treaty of Paris was signed the Indians were not mentioned. It was strange that this should have happened, especially as the English statesmen knew how valuable their aid had been."

I cannot see what purpose is served by bringing this up here.

I also note that Crowfoot, the outstanding Indian leader of the West, only gets passing mention. (In the R.C.M.P. chapter) Surely he should be included among the "Stories of Great Indians".

Page 86. "they (the Indians) found the English more harsh in their attitude" in comparison with the French. This is by way of explaining away Pontiac's treachery. I cannot see any useful purpose being served by a comparison of the two white races.

Page 94. "Tecumseh - Man of Vision".
"In the history of the Western world Pontiac and Tecumseh will always be linked together. Both were men of great ambitions for their people and both had the gift of leadership, etc."

A rather unhappy choice for the start of biographical material on the great Tecumseh!

Page 108. Tom Longboat.
"In his later years Tom Longboat worked for the Toronto Street Cleaning Department and the white-haired Indian was often pointed out --- as one of Canada's great athletes who had done his bit for his country in war and in peace."

Hardly an encouraging comment for youth. The reward for prowess and serving one's country?

It is noted that two sections are devoted to World War I and only one to World War II. This should be reversed, surely.

Page 124. High Steel.
"It has been mentioned earlier in this book that Indians have never been much interested in farming."
Page 124. (Cont'd)

The settled life of the farmer has few attractions for them.

"In recent years, however, some Indians particularly the Iroquois of Caughnawaga have found a new occupation which has in it as much excitement as the chase."

Hardly an approach designed to encourage young farmers-to-be!

Admin. Officer.
Mr. G. J. Bustess,
J. M. Dent & Sons,
224, Bloor Street West,
Toronto, Ont.

Dear Colonel Neary,

I was very pleased to see you again last week. This letter is just to tell you that I saw Mr. Eric Acland about the revision of Mr. Woodley's manuscript.

He was interested in this project, but he has in mind the completion of a boys' book for the Winston Company, publishers. This work will probably occupy him this winter but he expects to be free to tackle our job early next year.

When in Montreal I spoke to Mr. Woodley about this matter and he is agreeable to our using his material as a basis for the book that Mr. Acland will write.

We are attempting something rather difficult and personally I am very hopeful that we can keep Mr. Acland's interest in undertaking this work. There is the additional advantage that he lives in Ottawa and can keep in close touch with you.

It may take us a little time to get this manuscript in proper shape but I think the effort will be worth-while. I think it will be possible for us to publish this manuscript, once it has been found satisfactory by your department, in time for school opening next year. In the meanwhile, would you be good enough to have typed out copies of the two reports submitted by your readers (one of them was Mr. Acland, I believe) so that I can make a submission of them to Mr. Woodley who naturally has a right to know what we are going to do with this material. I may say that he is quite agreeable to us rewriting it and realizes that his style is not suitable for the purpose we have in mind, but he points out, of course, that he did a considerable amount of research on the material and therefore has a proprietary interest in what is to be done with it.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

C. J. Mustace

Re: Cataloguing Equipment and Supplies

At a recent meeting of the teachers and agent of the Tyendinaga Reserve, the above subject was discussed. We feel that it is desirable that all equipment and supplies on hand in the schools should be catalogued, and that the equipment at least should be checked at regular intervals. This would protect the teacher, enable us to transfer equipment from one school to another without the teacher carrying any of the responsibilities, enable us to list requirements with the minimum of work, and finally in the event of a change of teachers, both the new and the old teacher would be protected.

The Ontario Department of Education has a standard type of catalogue, but this does not meet with my approval because we want a type of catalogue that could be used for checking purposes over a number of years. With the Ontario Catalogue it is necessary to erase the check marks each year, or as is usually done, write out a list of the equipment each year and check from this written list. If your Department has no standard catalogue in supply, I would be in favor of using No.200 Government of Canada Register, with a supply of Index Tabs. We would require at least 3 of these books to start with.

We also discussed the cataloguing of Library Books. Some of our Schools are building up a nice library and consequently it is proving quite a chore to find any particular book. We are therefore interested in systems of cataloguing libraries. If the Department has no standard system in their schools, we would like to catalogue books according to the subjects on our curriculum. This system has many disadvantages, but I feel its simplicity outweighs them all. We would require for our book shelves some type of metal card holder. I would suggest that 3 dozen of these would be sufficient at the present time.

D.R.CASSE, Supt. Tyendinaga Agency.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Teachers, Indian Superintendents and School Inspectors have been constantly demanding additional storage space in many of our Indian day schools across the country.

Some of the Indian Superintendents had arranged to purchase material and hire Indian labour to construct shelves with suitable doors and locks. This process has been rather expensive. The Department has, therefore, undertaken to secure a suitable cupboard that would be large and strong enough to hold all the stock and school supplies under lock and key as required and yet make an economical buy.

After canvassing a great number of manufacturers it was decided that the best buy was from Canadian Public Booth Company Limited, Arnprior, Ontario. We attach the quotations received. This company has quoted a price of $58.00 f.o.b. Arnprior, Ontario.

These cabinets are 75 inches high, 35 inches wide and 20 inches deep and are made of birch with panel ends and doors with five adjustable shelves and equipped with elbow catch and cupboard locks. This company will do the crating and shipping without cost to the Department.
It is recommended, therefore, that the storage cabinets manufactured by Canadian Public Booth Company Limited be supplied to our schools when requested by requisition.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Colonel Neary,

Last May when we had the pleasure of discussing with you the work of the Audubon Society, and the placing of Canadian Nature in your schools, you advised us subscription orders would probably reach us about October last. As we have not yet heard from you in reply to our letter of the 25th September on this subject, we are afraid it may not have reached you, and therefore enclose a copy.

In our interview you mentioned your excellent method of building up school libraries by purchasing annually a book for each pupil in a school. In view of the fact that none of the Indian schools received Canadian Nature for 1948, 1949 and 1950, we are now writing to bring to your attention the Bound Volumes for these years.

These are interesting and informative volumes, and we know from experience that your schools will be grateful to you for making this material available to them. Each volume contains approximately 64 articles, 88 full colour illustrations, 161 photographs and 141 line drawings, all fully indexed. Single copies are $2.50 each, but for your schools we now offer you sets of the three volumes for only $5.00 a set - a saving of one-third. We would suggest that sets of these be obtained for at least the boarding schools and larger day schools. In order that you may be able to see them for yourself, and show them to your inspectors, we are sending you a set under separate cover.

None of the material in these books will be reprinted, and when the present stock is sold no further bound volumes for these years will be available. As less than a thousand volumes of each are still in stock, and the demand is heavy, we would suggest you advise your estimated requirements - say up to 250 sets - and we will reserve them for you, and you may order them shipped to your schools over the next few months as desired.

We trust we may have the pleasure of serving you and your schools in their study of the important subjects of nature and conservation.

Sincerely yours,

(A. R. Whitemore)
Editor

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Tape Recorder

Before I left for James Bay I submitted a request for a recording device without explaining its purpose and usefulness in the in-service training of teachers and objective evaluation of school activities.

The machine permits, without interruption to classroom procedure, the taking of significant excerpts of the teacher's performance or the children's recitations, and these excerpts can be played back later in discussions with the teacher.

It makes possible the provision of instruction to teachers in the ideal way to present material and to stimulate pupil-response. I would have selections of this sort made by experts who excel in voice and manner. Some of our teachers are sadly in need of models to imitate in the auditory field.

It would be possible to carry into the classroom ideally phrased messages from various officials of the Branch who cannot conveniently visit remote schools.

I should like to bring back from surveys and visitations on which stenographic aid is impracticable, the spoken opinions of persons interviewed and a better record of the proceedings than memory or brief notes can provide.
Conferences and interviews could proceed without the halts required for note taking.

The machine would serve to economize time in place of personal dictation to stenographers at Headquarters, and production of reports, memoranda and correspondence would proceed unimpeded by the lack of staff.

G.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant enclosing copies of two letters in connection with a toilet compound which you wish to try at the Oka Schools.

In reply I wish to point out that this compound, according to the letter written to Mr. D.R. Cassie, is referred to as "chemical toilet compound" and it is not known if it can be used in outside toilets.

As you know both the Village and Country Schools at Oka have ordinary flush toilets in the Teachers' Residences and outside ones for the pupils.

However as the above is probably being shipped by now we will further advise in the matter.

(Frs. Brisebois)

CIRCULAR LETTER - ALL TEACHERS:

A number of inquiries have been received in this office as to what period should be observed for Christmas holidays by our Indian Day Schools. To avoid confusion and to secure uniformity, Indian Day Schools in British Columbia will conform with the dates set by the Provincial Department of Education, which are as follows:

December 19th, 1950 - Schools close for Christmas Vacation.

January 3rd, 1951 - Schools re-open.

Recent visits of inspection have indicated that The Pupils' Own Vocabulary Spellers are not being used in accordance with the instructions which are to be found at the beginning of each of the three books and headed "How to Use Your Book". Teachers should follow these directions. The pupils should use a separate exercise book for this subject.

Some of our Catholic Schools are using the Faith and Freedom series as the basic readers for Grades 1 and 2. In future all schools, Catholic and Protestant, will use The Curriculum Foundation Series in Grades 1 to 3 and the Canadian Parade Readers in Grades 4 to 6, inclusive. Any Catholic school not using this Series should requisition for them now and place the word "Urgent" at the head of the requisition. The Faith and Freedom Series will be used as supplementary readers when the new series is received.

Teachers should keep on file in the school copies of requisitions which they forward to the Department.

Guide Books for the use of the teacher accompany both the Curriculum Foundation and Canadian Parade Readers series and teachers are required to use them in preparing their lessons.

I have been pleased to note that almost all teachers are now using Plan Books. Unfortunately, some teachers have been recording in these books the days work after it has been completed. It is expected that teachers will show in these books their plans for the succeeding day instead of using them as a record of work accomplished.

The Department has decided that in schools where religious instruction is given, the school day will be lengthened by the amount of time devoted to religious instruction, unless local conditions prevent this. Should your school be unable to lengthen the school day by the equivalent time, the Superintendent of your Indian Agency should be informed so that the possibility of overcoming local difficulties may be thoroughly explored.

R. F. DAVEY,

CIRCULAR LETTER - ALL TEACHERS:

A number of inquiries have been received in this office as to what period should be observed for Christmas holidays by our Indian Day Schools. To avoid confusion and to secure uniformity, Indian Day Schools in British Columbia will conform with the dates set by the Provincial Department of Education, which are as follows:

December 19th, 1950 - Schools close for Christmas Vacation.

January 3rd, 1951 - Schools re-open.

Recent visits of inspection have indicated that The Pupils' Own Vocabulary Spellers are not being used in accordance with the instructions which are to be found at the beginning of each of the three books and headed "How to Use Your Book". Teachers should follow these directions. The pupils should use a separate exercise book for this subject.

Some of our Catholic Schools are using the Faith and Freedom series as the basic readers for Grades 1 and 2. In future all schools, Catholic and Protestant, will use The Curriculum Foundation Series in Grades 1 to 3 and the Canadian Parade Readers in Grades 4 to 6, inclusive. Any Catholic school not using this Series should requisition for them now and place the word "Urgent" at the head of the requisition. The Faith and Freedom Series will be used as supplementary readers when the new series is received.

Teachers should keep on file in the school copies of requisitions which they forward to the Department.

Guide Books for the use of the teacher accompany both the Curriculum Foundation and Canadian Parade Readers series and teachers are required to use them in preparing their lessons.

I have been pleased to note that almost all teachers are now using Plan Books. Unfortunately, some teachers have been recording in these books the days work after it has been completed. It is expected that teachers will show in these books their plans for the succeeding day instead of using them as a record of work accomplished.

The Department has decided that in schools where religious instruction is given, the school day will be lengthened by the amount of time devoted to religious instruction, unless local conditions prevent this. Should your school be unable to lengthen the school day by the equivalent time, the Superintendent of your Indian Agency should be informed so that the possibility of overcoming local difficulties may be thoroughly explored.

R. F. DAVEY,
Regional Inspector of Indian Schools
for B.C.

ANNUAL SCHOOL SUPPLY REQUISITIONS

As the Department operates the most widely scattered school system in Canada, supplying the needs of our schools must be a systematic procedure and each teacher and principal is urged to shoulder his or her responsibility.

In order that the Stationery Branch can handle the flood of requisitions, it is necessary to have them spaced over the twelve month year as follows:

1. Requisitions to reach the Department by December 31, 1950, or as soon thereafter as possible.
   (a) from all residential schools
   (b) from day schools in the Yukon, Northwest Territories and in the Northern parts of the province where mail and freighting facilities are limited (e.g., Norway House Agency).

2. Requisitions to reach the Department by March 31, 1951.
   (a) from all day schools in British Columbia and Alberta.
   (b) for all library and supplementary books (special order form will appear in the next issue of the Bulletin).

3. Requisitions to reach the Department by May 31, 1951.
   (a) from all other day schools than those mentioned in 1 (b) and 2 (a) above.

Order Forms To Be Used

The Department has again decided to publish this order booklet as a supplement to the Indian School Bulletin. Attached hereto you will find the following requisition forms:

(a) Standard School Supplies - Stationery
(b) Standard text books
(c) Form for ordering text books required by Provincial Course of Study.

The purpose of this pad is to make easier the ordering of the main list of supplies and books for the next term. The extra pages are for supplementary requirements as necessary from time to time. For all other requirements use the "Requisition for School Material Form I.A. A13". If ordering a few books or supplies listed on the attached forms or Form I.A. A13, please quote the stock number at all times, as this will avoid delay.
Standard School Supplies - Stationery

Please adhere closely to this scale of issue in requisitioning supplies, otherwise, your requisition will be reduced accordingly. If you feel that your request warrants special consideration, please express your views by letter directed to the local Indian Superintendent and forward it to him attached to the requisition.

Scale of Issue:

(a) Pencil Sharpener - one per classroom

(b) Foolscap - 50 sheets per pupil in Grade 5 and upwards

(c) Loose Leaf Notebooks # 1973 - one per pupil in Grade 7
    two per pupil in Grade 8

(d) Loose Leaf Notebooks # 2933 - two per pupil in Grade 9
    and upwards

(Note: Ruled refills are available for above)

(e) Crayons - Wax crayons are provided for Grades 1 to 3
    Crayolas are available for Grade 4 and upwards.

(f) Modelling clay is available at the rate of a quarter or a pound to each pupil in Grade 1.

(for modelling by older pupils use paper-mache,
or plaster-of-Paris or flour, salt and water.)

(g) Dry Tempera: We provide a set of assorted colors for classroom use. Special Tempera brushes are provided for schools where teachers are doing Tempera work in Primary grades.

(h) Water colour boxes are provided for Grade 4 and upwards. Boxes should be used over and over again and refills ordered rather than discarding boxes when colours have been used up.

(i) Oil paints and pastels are provided for Grade 7 and upwards, provided that these are required by the Provincial Course of Study or the teacher has had training or experience in this line of work.

(j) White water colour drawing paper is provided for Grade 6 and upwards only. Lower grades will use Blank Drawing Books and Kraft Wrapping Paper for larger work, friezes, etc.

(k) Poster Paper is provided for Grade 6 and upwards only.

(l) Multiscript Paper: 1000 sheets per classroom only unless a magazine is being printed. (This paper is provided for stencil type duplicators only)

(m) Typewriter Paper: 1000 sheets per classroom only unless a magazine is being printed. (This paper is provided for gelatin type of duplicator or repeater pad duplicator or gelatin tray).

(n) Six scratch pads of each type are provided per classroom.
(c) Speedball Pen Nibs: we provide these only in boxes of 6 assorted widths in the round style. These are excellent for making posters, reading charts, flash cards, etc. Scale is 1 box per classroom.

Standard Text Books

The Provincial Department of Education are narrowing their selections to one or two sets of readers. The Standard reader in use in practically all provinces for Grades 1 to 3 is "The Basic Readers of the Curriculum Foundation Series."

In certain Catholic schools, the Faith and Freedom series is used. Other Catholic schools prefer to use the same readers as used in the Provincial schools. The Department will again provide one or the other of the readers but not both unless specifically authorized by the Provincial School Inspectors concerned.

For Grade 4 and upwards the schools again will be allowed a choice of the Canadian Parade Readers or the Canadian Reading Development Series - depending on which series is authorized for the province. All others will order the readers authorized for the Province in which the school is located.

Spellers:

Most of our teachers are familiar with the "Pupils' Own Vocabulary Spellers" now authorized in several provinces. These spellers have been so well accepted that we are making them available again.

Manual Training:

You will notice that "Second Year Woodwork" is now available.

Art:

Leading authorities on the teaching of classroom art are agreed that the use of large paper and large brushes are easier to handle by small children. They are also agreed that small children should do more art work with Dry Tempera colours and Dry Tempera brushes. Teachers coming from Normal Schools and from Summer Schools have been very enthusiastic with the results after putting this theory into practice. Consequently, the Department is making available the Dry Tempera colours for all grades. The Dry Tempera brushes are made available also. (These brushes have a long handle and coarse bristles and may be used by all grades).

For large paper, the Department is providing -

(i) Kraft Wrapping Paper for the lower grades, which can be used as drawing paper on one side and finger painting paper on the reverse side,

(ii) Large white drawing paper - for Grades 7 and upwards.

Some Provincial Courses of Study demand art work in oils for Grade 7 and up. Many teachers have also taken training in this line of work. The Department, is therefore prepared to supply the paints in tubes and special oil paint brushes to meet the demands for this type of materials. These will normally be supplied to the larger schools.

MEMORANDUM - Mr. W. S. Arneill

I refer to Mr. Phelan's letter of December 13, concerning my circular letter to teachers dated November 30, 1950, in which instructions were given concerning the use of certain Readers in the Catholic Indian Schools of this province.

At the time of the issuance of this circular I was aware of the instructions that had been given teachers in the Indian School Bulletins of November, 1950 and November, 1949. My interpretation of these instructions is that I am empowered to authorize the use of both of these Readers, although the wording in the Bulletin refers to Provincial School Inspectors. Naturally, I assumed that the Department confers upon me the same authority that it delegates to School Inspectors not directly under the control of the Department.

The only material difference between the instructions included in the Bulletin and the action taken by myself is in indicating how these two sets will be used. It is my considered opinion that the Curriculum Foundation Series and the Canadian Parade Readers are superior to the Faith and Freedom and Corona Readers. Consequently, I indicated that the first two named sets should be used as the basic Readers.

I did not consider that I had gone beyond the bounds of authority which should be assumed by an Inspector of Schools or the authority as suggested in the Indian School Bulletins of November 1949 and 1950. Since the Department is prepared to supply the two series when requested by the Inspector, surely he is entitled to indicate how these should be used.

R. F. Davey,
Regional Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ont.

I might mention also that certain Catholic Schools are believed to have expressed a preference for the Canadian Parade Readers. I can see Mr. Davey's point of view in the matter but we will of course be guided by the Department's instructions.

W.S. Arnell,

BRITANNICA JUNIOR is unusual for several reasons but chiefly because it is planned for boys and girls of the elementary grades only, and handles the material in the simple, fresh manner that is thoroughly acceptable to these young people.

Since BRITANNICA JUNIOR was published with the cooperation of the University of Chicago, every device of modern educators was employed to make the set useful and appealing to the age group for which it is designed. Subjects for entry were carefully selected with school curricula as guides; scientific studies assured the choice of a vocabulary comprehensible to children; even the type face used was selected by a sample group of boys and girls. The result is an interesting, direct treatment that is easily understood and enjoyed. An example of the informal presentation is this vivid start to the article on "Arbitration" — "The umpire calls 'strike three!' and the batter is out. Both baseball teams have agreed in advance to accept this official's decision on every disputed point."

The illustrations are diversified and appealing — photographs, three-color drawings, charts, pictographs, reproductions in color, and several types of maps. Locator maps are an interesting departure to show the site of products and industries, streets, notable buildings, islands, rivers and political divisions. The excellent use of visual aids is indicated by the material accompanying the article on boxing. There are drawings of a Roman match, a series on modern boxing, and two reproductions of fight scenes by George Bellows.

An important feature of the set is the "Ready Reference" volume, which serves as an index to the encyclopedia and also provides excellent definitions and identifications. Examination of the index demonstrates how wide are the interests of the modern elementary-school child, and how seriously BRITANNICA JUNIOR takes these interests. Listed are articles on every conceivable subject from flowers and the Planetarium to the Tennessee Valley Authority and electronics. Biographical articles, too, are well represented, with listings for world figures as well as for persons of special appeal to youngsters.

A final outstanding feature of the set is the format. Type face is unusually clear and readable; illustrations are effective; page make-up as a whole is exceptionally attractive.

It has taken several revisions and many improvements for this set to become a first-rate children's encyclopaedia. Now, with the new edition for a limited age group, BRITANNICA JUNIOR has made a place for itself."
Boys' and Girls' Encyclopaedia

"Britannica Junior." Prepared under the direction of the editors of the Encyclopaedia Britannica Company, Toronto; 15 volumes, $90.

Next to a good teacher, the most valuable educational factor in a pupil's life is a good reference collection. These are three indispensable basic elements to a school library. They are: a reliable dictionary, an accurate atlas, and an interesting and authoritative encyclopaedia. Having these three essentials in hand, the school can add as many individual books on various subjects as it wishes.

A careful examination of Britannica Junior shows that it combines the best features of all dictionary, atlas and encyclopaedia. This reviewer was thrilled as he pitted through the volumes, read the articles and looked at the many pictures. Britannica Junior has always been one of the best children's encyclopaedias, and the new printing is a great improvement. It is recommended for elementary schools and junior high school grades with scarcely any reservation.

As the editors indicate, Britannica Junior is written for boys and girls of the elementary grades, but the material is so well written that they will find it interesting. It is obvious that a good deal of thought and skill have been used in preparing each article. Each writing is a masterpiece of interesting presentation. Teachers who know the value of reference books in getting pupils to use reference books will appreciate the fascinating way in which the articles in this encyclopaedia are written. The reader is constantly reminded with introductory sentences or each article which are calculated to lure the child to read further.

Big words are avoided and the style is simple, but accuracy and thoroughness are not lacking. An encyclopaedia for a child is something different from one for an adult. The editors of Britannica Junior look for scholarly details of an advanced nature, the child's wants are considered. The editors of Britannica Junior have wisely recognized this in selecting the material to be included in the text.

There are several features of the new encyclopaedia that are worthy of special mention. First is its appearance. The volumes are beautiful to look at. The initial attractiveness is sustained throughout. The make-up editors are to be congratulated on the smart appearance of the pages and the attractive arrangement of headings. They are a definite improvement over those in the previous printing. The type face is also improvement, too. The new type face is larger and easier to read.

The volumes are profusely illustrated. Color is used not only in the full page photographs, but also in a number of smaller pictures. The art work throughout is outstanding. A feature of this set is the color reproductions of famous paintings obtained from the Encyclopaedia Britannica collection of modern American painting.

Volume 1, the "ready reference" volume, is a jewel. Offering quick information on thousands of topics, it is an invaluable time-saver and an index to the set. The editors have been particularly concerned for the clear and picturesque way of explaining how to use this volume.

The atlas at the end of volume 15 has 81 colored plates, and throughout the set there are many "locator"
maps which give the students a clear idea of the products and points of interest of each country or province and show the location of a country, province or city in relation to its neighboring territories.

There are many useful charts, tables and diagrams.

The interesting way in which articles are introduced has been mentioned. An example may be cited from the piece on the kingfisher:

"If you should chance to be on the bank of some small stream and suddenly see a flash of blue above fall like a meteor upon the water's surface, without feeling doubtful you could say 'That is a kingfisher.'"

Slightly more than a page is devoted to the kingfisher, including a picture.

The article on Saskatchewan properly begins with an account of the province's agricultural operations. It explains the meaning of "Saskatchewan," gives its location, and presents a historical sketch. There is a good paragraph on other industries, a description of life and activities in the northern part of the province, and information about the aboriginal people and their sports, recreation and cultural activities. The importance of Regina as a center is clearly indicated. There is a full page "locator" map and another map about two-thirds of a column deep showing the physical features and places.

It is important to test spelling growth during the year and for this purpose we submit MID-YEAR Spelling Tests from the spelling lists of each grade in THE CANADIAN PUPILS' OWN VOCABULARY SPELLERS.

HOW TO ADMINISTER THE TEST

Dictate each word in the completion sentence given and then repeat the word alone for the pupils to write.

MARKING THE TEST

In marking the tests give the pupils credit for the number of correct words in the test and allow three marks for each correct word e.g., 30 correct words = 90 marks. If the child has over 92 marks he can do the spelling of the next grade. If he has under 75 he should be given the spelling of a lower grade.

Note: We will have Final Tests similar in type to the Mid-Year Tests given here.

ARE YOU FOLLOWING "The Plan for Individual Weekly Review"?

"Words missed on Friday should be correctly recorded at the end of the lesson. If possible, misspelled words should be studied immediately after the test is taken. The source of each error should be sought and the correct form given special attention. The pupil should be encouraged to refer again to the dictionary and to seek the teacher's help freely on these words. Dictionaries appear at the back of each book beginning with Grade IV. Each child should study his misspelled words again on Thursday of the following week and include them in his Friday test. If he misses the word again the same process should be repeated.

If after this second study the child still misses the word, he should record it correctly in a list of his own hard words."

River of the Sun

By James Ramsey Ullman

This superb novel, which was the Book-of-the-Month Club choice for January, blends excellent adventure with intellectual stimulation. Like the unforgettable The White Man's Burden, it explores the psychology of living against a background of hazardous experiences.

There are three stories, and one besides. From the Andes to the plains between the Isthmus and the Amazon, follows the course of the forest. It is in this forest valley, the Amazon valley, that the action of the story takes place.

Billion, ex-Army pilot, has buried himself in a routine job in the town of Manaus, trying to forget the past adventure which his wife was killed. He is persuaded by his friend, Berman, seeking the fabled River of the Sun, resolved to flee through the valley rich in gold and gems. With the party is Christine, wife of Dr. Nils Barna, who is going up-river to find his missing wife. Unexpectedly, the expedition discovers a new river, and searches for Dr. Barna, who has disappeared into the enveloping wilderness.

Mighty rivers, dense jungles, mood of steaming jungle and mysterious rivers, where the map shows only a blank spot marked "Unexplored," and against this setting is woven a story of thrilling adventures. But behind the excitement lies the real theme of the book—a man seeking something outside and beyond himself, for a goal in life, for inner peace. $4.25

The Faith of Mrs. Kelleen

By Katherine Mary Flannigan

Remember Mrs. Mike, that fine story of an Irish coltress who married a Montana? Real life "Mrs. Mike" was Katherine Mary Flannigan, and now she has written a book of her life, though in the form of fiction, it is based on actual events in the life of her great-aunt.

It happened eighty years ago in Montana. Mrs. Mike's great-aunt Kelleen lived with her son Rory, the first boy of eighteen. When Rory took two young horses to sell at the county fair, and then returned late at night, his mother was sick with worry. In the morning, the police came to arrest him, he had been accused of murdering one of the Mustangs, a horse trader.

White Man Boss

By Adamastor

In South Africa today there is a regime reminiscent of Hitler's. It is presided over by Dr. Daniel Malan, Prime Minister and head of the Nationalist Party. One of its basic tenets is the doctrine of racial superiority, and in keeping with this belief the natives are rigorously segregated and discriminated against. The Afrikaners, who were outspoiled and disarmed during the war, called themselves "Die Volk," a name that calls to mind the "Herero" of the German Southwest.

Dr. Malan said in 1941: "Hereby we declare that our republic shall not be like the state we have at the moment, in which the liberalistic British parliamentary system is imposed upon us. We want a race one gets if one gives the franchise to everyone indiscriminately?"

Adamastor (the real name of a prominent South African author) answers with his denunciation of the fanatical Afrikaner tribe which 300 years ago cut the ties with Europe and became victims of the savagery that is inherent in the culture of older Africa." $3.00

Time, which does not bestow praise lightly, described it as "a highly popular treatise of the facts and fiction of heredity."

A West-India Fortune

By Richard Pares

In 1685 one Azariah Pinney, who had been involved in Monmouth's Rebellion, was exiled to the West Indies. This is the story of the Pinneys and their fortune, its growth during nearly two centuries. He That Plays the King

By Kenneth Tynan

Ken Tynan, a youthful prodigy who is already a successful theatre producer at the age of twenty-three, was once considered a great dramatic critic in the making, but now he seems to have lost interest in the theatre. This volume of criticisms displays both the exuberance of youth and the maturely intelligent love of the theatre. Mr. Tynan is whole-hearted in either enthusiasm, but he has lost patience with the lukewarm comments of the critics. "Criticism," he says, "has taken a wrong turning into a perturbability of mind which it has succeeded in worry about communicating excitement or sense."

The author is an unabashed hero-worshipper, and his book is concerned largely with larger drama. However, he turns aside occasionally to pulverize some minor play or to defend the ageing shopworn D'Orly Carte Opera Company with its affected style and wide, ironic smile. Too many spurious phrases issuing from the spasmodic freezes. While we are here, there are a couple of other quotable lines: "Olivier would pounce on a line and rip its heart out," "Richard III skips a beat and bounces along it, shaving off pathos in great flakes." And his description of an actor's "ceaseless..."
fits of wrestling with his cloak, like a tortoise in a philosophical mood.

There is a stimulating introduction by Orson Welles, who applauds some of Mr. Tyran's judgments and takes sharp issue with others.

$3.00

The Incredible De Foe

By William Freeman

The author of Robinson Crusoe—who gave the dramatic "De" to his plain name of Foe—lived in turbulent times that marked his own life. In his youth he saw London ravaged by the Plague and the Great Fire; five years later he died. During his lifetime, he witnessed the effect of Monmouth's Rebellion, the restoration of the last Stuart, and the accession of William of Orange.

As a young man, Daniel De Foe was a businessman of varied interests, whose deals ranged from buying and selling ships to the purchase of a farm of civet cats. But his energy and ambition were greater than his business sense, and his ideas of honesty were, say his biographers, platonic. He was bankrupt twice, was twice imprisoned in Newgate, and stood for a seat in Parliament. Nevertheless, he had a fundamental respect for credit and justice, and paid off his creditors by paying off twelve thousand pounds in the end.

William Freeman has done more than bring us the life of an amazing man. He has given us, too, a wealth of curious and fascinating detail, the England in which De Foe lived.

$8.50

The Magic People

By Arland Usher

Arland Usher, whose brilliant and provocative The Face and Mind of Ireland has been enthusiastically received both in this country and elsewhere, now writes of the Jews.

He begins with a survey of the history and character of the Jewish people as revealed in the Old Testament. He goes on to discuss the nature of Jesus as symbol, not only of the Jew but of Jewry. This leads to the subject of the Jewish religion and Jesus as the Messiah, and some interesting speculations as to what would have happened to Christianity if they had accepted him. Finally he reaches the core of the book, an analysis of antisemitism, and puts forward many explanations on many levels. It quite rightly, for anti-Semitism is a complex phenomenon, with roots in all kinds of soil.

This is a most stimulating book, the product of an unusual mind and a true believer's intuition. It overflows with unorthodox and often brilliant ideas, expressed in a style that makes reading a pleasure.

$2.50

We Two

By Ulrik Atlebek

The theme of We Two is one of the simplest and most powerful in the world—a mother's love for her baby. Before she is even aware she is going to have a baby, the mother experiences, wonderfully sensitively, the emotions of pregnancy, of the actual birth, of first holding the baby, of watching the sensations she feels on the baby's first crying, waking, feeding, talking, and answering her questions about life.

Dealing with intense emotions, the story yet avoids falling into sentimentality. Readers are put in direct contact with the feelings of the mother, experiencing them almost as their own.

$2.75

INFORMATION ON
BUCKEYE PASTE WAX and
BUCKEYE CLEANING and POLISHING WAX

These two waxes are the original types of wax polish. They contain various kinds of waxes blended together with solvents of naphtha, turpentine, benzine, or mineral spirit type. They contain more wax solids than so-called "water emulsion" or "no rubbing" type of wax, and actually are less expensive in the long run than "water emulsion" wax.

However, from the standpoint of time and labour, these waxes are more expensive since they require longer to polish.

Cleaning and Polishing Spirit Wax is merely Buckeye Paste Wax thinned out with an excellent cleaning agent.

Use Buckeye Paste Wax or Cleaning & Polishing Wax on hardwood floors for better results.

Buckeye Cleaning & Polishing Wax can be used also, on all types of linoleums, but is not recommended where there is extremely heavy and dirty traffic. However, it does give the finest finish of any wax, but is a little more difficult to maintain.

HOW TO APPLY BUCKEYE PASTE and BUCKEYE CLEANING & POLISHING WAXES:

In applying Paste Wax, a thin, even coat is the secret of good waxing.

Wood floors should be WAXED ACROSS THE GRAIN and POLISHED WITH THE GRAIN.

Allow about five minutes to dry and polish with a soft, clean cloth...a weighted brush...or an electric polisher.

One advantage of Buckeye Cleaning & Polishing Wax is that it cleans and polishes at the same time...can be applied faster than Paste Wax, and is fairly easy to apply.

It also makes an outstanding polish for furniture and woodwork of any colour.

Do not use either one of the above waxes on composition floors...mastic or asphalt tile, or rubber flooring.

The solvents contained in these types of waxes sometimes take out the colours, and actually will dissolve mastic or asphalt tile.

INFORMATION ON
BUCKEYE SELF-SHINE WAX

In addition to "Self-Shine" this product answers variously to the names: "No Buff," "Self-Polishing," "Water Emulsion," and "Water Wax." It is, basically, a blend of waxes and shellac dispersed in a solution of water and colloidal soap.

After application, the water evaporates, depositing the minute particles of wax in a uniform film. These tiny particles reflect light and give a glossy, lustrous sheen without rubbing or buffing.

Walking over, sweeping, and mopping a floor coated with Self-Shine Wax all tend to burnish and increase the gloss. Some users prefer to buff Self-Shine to achieve the maximum lustre right away... this can be done with a weighted brush or an electric polisher.

Self-Shine enables one man to wax and polish double or more the floor area than he could by the old method. It also eliminates fire hazards, bad odours—common to paste or liquid waxes.

Covers from 3600 to 5400 square feet per gallon, depending upon porosity of the surface and variations in application.

Dries non-tacky in about twenty minutes unless there is exceptional humidity or poor ventilation.

Self-Shine Wax is waterproof when thoroughly dry. This permits mopping with cold water without removing the wax. It also explains resistance to spilled liquids, rain, etc.

It can be removed with warm water and our neutral soap Perfection or Terrazine Floor Soap.

It is recommended particularly for linoleum of all kinds, rubber tile, cork flooring, composition floors, mastic or asphalt tile, and any floors which have a tightly sealed surface, such as terrazzo, tile or painted cement floors.

HOW TO APPLY
BUCKEYE SELF-SHINE WAX

Self-Shine Wax should be FLOWED on the floor in a thin, even film, using a suitable applicator. It should NOT BE RUBBED IN like Paste Wax and Cleaning and Polishing Wax.

Level the wax out, then leave it! Going back over the wax after the two or three minutes it takes to set, may cause streakiness.

Pouring a small quantity of the wax on the floor and spreading it out, may be satisfactory for a small floor, but an open container in which you can dip the applicator is better for large areas.

The wax should be applied in straight sweeps running the same way not in a circular motion.

Allow to dry for about 20 minutes... longer on humid days.

If buffing is intended, use a clean, soft cloth under a weighted brush, or an electric floor polisher. This method gives an excellent floor that will withstand heavy traffic.

CAUTION!

If any floor on which Buckeye Self-Shine Wax appears slippery, it is a sign that too much wax is being used.

Buckeye Self-Shine Wax has been passed by the Underwriter's Laboratories as being "ANTI-SLIP MATERIAL," but even with this guarantee, it is advisable where floors have a tendency to be slippery, to thin out the material from 10 to 15% with cold water. Each maintenance man can gauge the amount of water to be added for each type of flooring.

On terrazzo, painted cement floors or red tile, thin out the wax with water up to 40 or 50%.
