TO: Superintendents, Indian Agency, Regional Supervisors of Indian Agencies and the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia.

With reference to the Circular Letter of February 7, 1949, concerning Civil Service Regulation 85A, dealing with compensation for overtime for employees of the Civil Service, please note the following amended Regulations:

"Employees to whom this regulation applies shall be compensated by additional leave for overtime worked in accordance with the following conditions:

(a) that the overtime work was performed on the written instructions of an official authorized to give such instructions by the deputy head, with the concurrence of the Commission;

(b) that in the case of an employee required to register daily the time of his arrival and departure and in receipt of a salary not exceeding $3180. per annum, the period of overtime work is not less than one hour and was worked either on a statutory holiday (or other day declared a holiday by competent authority) or on a normal working day.

(c) that in the case of an employee earning over $3180. or who is not required to register daily the time of his arrival and departure, the period of overtime work was not less than three hours and was performed on a statutory holiday (or other day declared a holiday by competent authority);

(d) that the time of arrival and departure for such overtime work is properly recorded.

Leave may be granted to employees in compensation for overtime worked at the rate of one-half day's leave for each three hours' overtime, and this leave may be used for the same purpose and subject to the same conditions, including provision for carry-over between Departments as vacation leave, sick leave or special leave. This additional leave in compensation for overtime work may be used for vacation leave during the fiscal year in which the overtime is worked and the following fiscal year, and may be used for sick leave or special leave at any time up to the date of separation from the Service.

At the time an employee separates from the Service by resignation, retirement or for any reason other than misconduct, overtime leave available for use as vacation leave, may be treated as outstanding vacation leave, and overtime leave available for sick or special leave, may be used for the purpose of qualifying for retiring leave under Section 73 of these regulations."

Leave covered by overtime must be requested on the usual leave application form now in use, (Form No. 263).
Consideration has been given to the procedure for recording overtime under this regulation, and it has been decided that periods of overtime worked will be computed to the nearest completed half hour. That is to say, odd minutes in excess of the last completed half hour will not be recorded. For example, if an employee works overtime for a period of one hour and fifty minutes, he will be credited with one and a half hours; if he works two hours and five minutes, he will be credited with two hours.

All authorizations, (Form C.P. 300) for overtime work of the Indian Affairs field staff as set forth in the regulations, will be signed by the Superintendents. The forms will then be forwarded to the Regional Supervisors for their recommendation and submission to Head Office.

Referring to your letter of October 27th, please be advised that the compound sent for experimental purposes so far has not proven out very well. It may be that this compound will work satisfactorily during Spring and Summer. We have not yet had an opportunity to try it during the warm weather. Since it appears that to get maximum benefit from the compound, sewage matter will have to be covered with liquid at all times. I should imagine we are going to have to make metal containers for the toilets or line the present boxes with metal. I should like to hear if better success has been met with from other Agencies and under what circumstances.

Concerning the urinals you wanted placed in the boys' toilets, we have just now been able to obtain sheet aluminum. I have my doubts as to how this will work out as in some cases the seats are little more than a foot from the floor and the trouble would have to run into the box from the top of the seat. If it was just a case of having the drain-off into a hole in the ground instead of boxes as we have to contend with, there would be no problem at all. We tried this out some years ago and condemned it for unsatisfactory and unsanitary reasons.

Mr. W.S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.,

This refers to your letter of March 30th in connection with the local purchase of Permanent Record Cards and other supplies for the Indian schools in British Columbia.

The Department fully realizes the difficulties encountered in ordering supplies and books through Ottawa and the Department of Public Printing and Stationery, as there is still a considerable delay from the time the order is placed and goods are delivered. However, the Stationery Act is a law passed by Parliament and designates that all purchases of books and stationery must be handled through the Department of Public Printing and Stationery. This Department is very fussy to see that this law is complied with.

We have occasions in this office when it would be in the Public interest to authorize local purchase of books and supplies but we are reluctant to do so for this very reason.

The fact that Mr. Davey requires Programmes of Studies; Standardized Tests etc., from time to time is appreciated. However, it is felt that a reasonable estimate of future requirements can be made and when ordered through the usual channels delivery can be assured within a reasonable time.
It is readily understood that from time to time there will be emergency cases where urgent action will be required. In such cases, the Department will be prepared to authorize local purchase. However, this office should be informed of the situation.

We are not trying to be disagreeable; however, we have the Department of Public Printing and Stationery to contend with and we are just afraid that if the local purchase system is abused and the Stationery Office should refuse to pay such accounts, we would be in a very embarrassing position. I am certain you will understand.

We are passing the account for the Record Cards to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery for payment.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Memorandum:

MR. PHELAN

Re: Department of Public Printing and Stationery Accounts for Fiscal Year 1950-51

In the Summer of 1949, the Department of Public Printing and Stationery, after a survey decided to secure a number of tabulating machines from the International Business Machines Company to handle all the office book-keeping, billing, invoicing, ordering etc. These machines were to replace most of the book-keeping and typewriting procedures carried out by office staff in the past.

These machines were installed on September 6th and all work carried out by hand was discontinued as all the work was to be done by the machines. The result was that there was a long delay in getting the organization going as the staff was not trained to handle the machines. Colonel Neary and I protested to officials of the Public Printing and Stationery urging them to process our requisitions except those for the schools with the International Business Machines Company machines processing ours in the old manner until the staff became acquainted with the new set up to bring our division under this new arrangement. The Stationery Branch, however, could not see our way and held our requisitions in abeyance until they had the organization completed.

In December, 1949, I telephoned the Pre-Edit Section of the Department of Public Printing and Stationery asking them when they would commence our requisitions only to be advised that the required cards had been received from the suppliers but did not fit the machines and were returned, resulting in further delay.
Fortunately all requisitions received prior to September 6th were processed by the old system and the schools received their supplies before school opening.

In January, 1950, we were beginning to get very many complaints from teachers and principals that supplies ordered after September for emergency reasons were not being delivered. Again, we took the matter up with the Stationery Office but were informed that they were revising the catalogue and nothing could be done until such time as the catalogue was prepared.

We then took the matter up with the Director of Services who agreed to our proposition to ship the requirements and attend to the billing when the catalogue, the required cards and billing sheets were ready. The Department of Public Printing and Stationery agreed that they would make shipments from the date of requisition and forward them to the Pre-Edit Section for billing. We were assured by the Stationery officials at that time that all shipments made prior to February 28th, 1950 would be billed before March 31 of that year. However, this was not done. The Stationery Office did not commence their billing for this branch until June, 1951, with the result that many of the shipments affected during December, January and February, 1950, when the residential schools were having their orders for the 1951-52 academic year requirements met were not billed until the Summer of 1951.

When Mr. Dalton, present Chief of the Pre-Edit Section took over in October, 1950, there were 1200 of our filled requisitions on hand which had to go through the machines for billing purposes only as the shipments had been.

These outstanding billings have now been cleared up and today the Stationery has about sixty requisitions on hand which can be cleared in a week.

To summarize, on account of the delays encountered by the Department of Public Printing and Stationery, we are obliged to pay from the 1950-51 vote for all supplies requisitioned during the period September 6, 1949 to March 2, 1951, a period of nineteen months. It might be in order
to add that the months of December, January, February and March are the heaviest months as all the residential schools in the North and all British Columbia schools are obliged to order their supplies during these months. This arrangement was made for the convenience of the Stationery Office to avoid a last minute flood. This arrangement has caused us to pay for this heavy period twice out of one year's vote as the 1950-51 and 1951-52 requirements are billed on the 1950-51 vote.

Attached, are extracts from the Auditor-General's reports showing the comparisons between expenditures for salaries and school supplies.

I have worked out the figures in percentages and you will note that there was a steep decline in the figures for 1949-50 from the figures of 1948-49. This can mean only one thing, that many of the supplies requisitioned and shipped in 1950 were billed in 1951 for reasons already explained above.

During the past few years Colonel Neary had found from inspection of schools and talking with school inspectors a need for a more concrete type of seatwork material and after considerable correspondence, dickering with publishers we were able to secure a reasonably priced duplicator and Duplicopy Workbooks from the Company of Canada. A copy of the book is $2.52. We had fifteen assorted titles of these books and they were distributed to all the schools at the rate of one book for every five pupils with a maximum of fifteen for the school. This amounted to a considerable expense.

To encourage better attendance in the day schools, it was decided to provide the day schools who had an average percentage of attendance of between 70.00% and 79.99% with 5 bonus library books; those with between 80.00% and 89.99% with ten bonus books and those with over 90% with fifteen bonus books.
For the fiscal year 1949-50 the Auditor General's report states that $139,085.93 was spent by this Branch for Printing and Stationery Accounts. In view of the fact that for 1950-51, we are billed for nineteen months, eight of which are the heaviest months; the additional seatwork books and bonus books provided; the higher number of books in general and the new day and residential schools opened to which supplies were sent amounted to a considerably higher expenditure than previous years.

M.F. Track

INFORMATION ON
BUCKEYE PASTE WAX and
BUCKEYE CLEANING and POLISHING WAX

These two waxes are the original types of wax polish. They contain various kinds of waxes blended together with solvents of naphtha, turpentine, benzine, or mineral spirit type. They contain more wax solids than so-called "water emulsion" or "no rubbing" type of wax, and actually are less expensive in the long run than "water emulsion" wax.

However, from the standpoint of time and labour, these waxes are more expensive since they require longer to polish.

Cleaning and Polishing Spirit Wax is merely Buckeye Paste Wax thinned out with an excellent cleaning agent.

Use Buckeye Paste Wax or Cleaning & Polishing Wax on hardwood floors for better results.

Buckeye Cleaning & Polishing Wax can be used also, on all types of linoleums, but is not recommended where there is extremely heavy and dirty traffic. However, it does give the finest finish of any wax, but is a little more difficult to maintain.

HOW TO APPLY BUCKEYE PASTE and BUCKEYE CLEANING & POLISHING WAXES:

In applying Paste Wax, a thin, even coat is the secret of good waxing.

Wood floors should be WAXED ACROSS THE GRAIN and POLISHED WITH THE GRAIN.

Allow about five minutes to dry and polish with a soft, clean cloth...a weighted brush...or an electric polisher.

One advantage of Buckeye Cleaning & Polishing Wax is that it cleans and polishes at the same time...can be applied faster than Paste Wax, and is fairly easy to apply.

It also makes an outstanding polish for furniture and woodwork of any colour.

Do not use either one of the above waxes on composition floors...mastic or asphalt tile, or rubber flooring.

The solvents contained in these types of waxes sometimes take out the colours, and actually will dissolve mastic or asphalt tile.

INFORMATION ON
BUCKEYE SELF-SHINE WAX

In addition to "Self-Shine" this product answers variously to the names: "No Buff," "Self-Polishing," "Water Emulsion," and "Water Wax." It is, basically, a blend of waxes and shellac dispersed in a solution of water and colloidal soap.

After application, the water evaporates, depositing the minute particles of wax in a uniform film. These tiny particles reflect light and give a glossy, lustrous sheen without rubbing or buffing.

Walking over, sweeping, and mopping a floor coated with Self-Shine Wax all tend to burnish and increase the gloss. Some users prefer to buff Self-Shine to achieve the maximum lustre right away... this can be done with a weighted brush or an electric polisher.

Self-Shine enables one man to wax and polish double or more the floor area than he could by the old method. It also eliminates fire hazards, bad odours—common to paste or liquid waxes.

Covers from 3600 to 5400 square feet per gallon, depending upon porosity of the surface and variations in application.

Dries non-tacky in about twenty minutes unless there is exceptional humidity or poor ventilation.

Self-Shine Wax is waterproof when thoroughly dry. This permits mopping with cold water without removing the wax. It also explains resistance to spilled liquids, rain, etc.

It can be removed with warm water and our neutral soap Perfection or Terrazine Floor Soap.

It is recommended particularly for linoleum of all kinds, rubber tile, cork flooring, composition floors, mastic or asphalt tile, and any floors which have a tightly sealed surface, such as terrazzo, tile or painted cement floors.

HOW TO APPLY
BUCKEYE SELF-SHINE WAX

Self-Shine Wax should be FLOWED on the floor in a thin, even film, using a suitable applicator.

It should NOT BE RUBBED IN like Paste Wax and Cleaning and Polishing Wax.

Level the wax out, then leave it! Going back over the wax after the two or three minutes it takes to set, may cause streakiness.

Pouring a small quantity of the wax on the floor and spreading it out, may be satisfactory for a small floor, but an open container in which you can dip the applicator is better for large areas.

The wax should be applied in straight sweeps running the same way not in a circular motion.

Allow to dry for about 20 minutes... longer on humid days.

If buffing is intended, use a clean, soft cloth under a weighted brush, or an electric floor polisher. This method gives an excellent floor that will withstand heavy traffic.

CAUTION!

If any floor on which Buckeye Self-Shine Wax appears slippery, it is a sign that too much wax is being used.

Buckeye Self-Shine Wax has been passed by the Underwriter's Laboratories as being "ANTI-SLIP MATERIAL," but even with this guarantee, it is advisable where floors have a tendency to be slippery, to thin out the material from 10 to 15% with cold water. Each maintenance man can gauge the amount of water to be added for each type of flooring.

On terrazzo, painted cement floors or red tile, thin out the wax with water up to 40 or 50%.

Dear Mr. Track,

We are forwarding immediately a small carton of supplementary books for your inspection, as per our previous arrangements. Please forgive the delay in sending this display, but until very recently, I have been travelling almost continually.

In preparing this small but select display, I have tried to keep in mind the limitations you mentioned to me. Most of the books have a relatively mature interest level but limited vocabulary. There are no fairy tales or classics. Emphasis has been placed on outdoor life and crafts. Finally, I have tried to limit the price range to $2.75 retail, although in a few cases there are prices above this level. Incidentally, as you know, the prices indicated are subject to a 20% discount on your order.

You will find the attached list duplicated inside the carton of books. Where the book(s) represents a series, I have indicated the other available titles.

We are hoping to hear from you when you have had an opportunity to examine these books.

Yours sincerely,

S. G. Scott.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

In reply to the request for opinions on the library books, I would like to let you know that both my pupils and I are delighted with the Wonder Books and the Little Golden Books.

The story appeal is excellent. Odd stories are given adequate attention and there are charming new stories such as the Sky Little Horse and The Pisky Puppy. Imaginative stories about animals are valuable in teaching the children to be kind to animals. However, I thought that more realistic stories about other peoples and places could be included.

The children were not only interested in hearing the stories read or told, but showed a lively eagerness...
to read and re-read themselves. At first only a few were interested but as the year went on they all developed more interest.

The beautiful illustrations were an important factor in the children's increased desire to read. Many of the books have large illustrations that tell stories themselves. Many children asked about the pictures, they begged to have the stories read or tried to read them themselves. The pictures aroused curiosity, amply illustrate the stories and many unknown ideas to the children and stimulate conversation and language about the stories and characters. In fact, the children said "the pictures are the best part." Many lively imaginative drawings of the children's personal interpretations resulted from viewing the drawings.

The books held up very well in the classroom and I both felt the exterior and interior material pleasing and practical.
Regarding the vocabulary. On the whole it is excellent, but often a little difficult for my pupils, who are all about one year behind in reading. However, it is a good vocabulary for story-telling and language lessons, as it gives them a chance to become familiar with the words and widen their vocabulary.

I find the books excellent teaching material for language, pre-reading, reading, picture study, number work, social studies and other lessons. The pictures are clear and attractive, the language simple enough, and the stories very appealing and illustrate good behaviour.

Although I feel I still have too little experience to be really sure, I would like to recommend that some of the books, recommended as supplementary reading in the Guide Book to the Basic Readers, be chosen. I feel the children need more reading with a vocabulary that is in a line with their readers. I could
also use for poor readers more easy reading.

In the Teacher's Catalogue published by Educational Publishing Co., I find Books for Retarded Children advertised on page 41. They cost 30¢ ea. and I thought they might be very useful.

I would also like to see more easy reading about people of other nationalities and professions such as "The Two Little Miners."

Joe and Ruth are great favourites with all grades 1 to 5. Couldn't the book after Joe & Ruth be supplied?

Hope my letter is not too late.

Yours sincerely,

Edna Kibby

Educ. Div., Indian Affairs B.C.,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,

Dear Sir,

When I came to Little Pine Day School in 1947, there were practically no supplementary reading books for the thirty to forty children. This fall I brought the list of library books up to number one hundred and eighty-eight, thanks to our Education Division.

Little Pine Children have taken very good care of their Library Books. Very few have been torn, and almost none written in, though "a story book in every desk" (from grade one up) is our custom.
I teach the juniors, and notice they do enjoy animal stories and stories of children, even city children. Short stories in larger print are enjoyed more than longer ones as they read them faster and feel they have accomplished something easily. They love the brighter pictures, funny ones and ones of birds, animals etc., which they already know. Being observant, they often dive into their desk for a story-book illustration relative to some lesson or discussion.

My children like poetry but find it difficult to read to themselves.

The seniors enjoy stories a grade or two below their school grade in difficulty. Books with small print, or long stories are avoided, I think, because the children feel they are too difficult. The teacher needs
3. To read aloud the first chapter or two to arouse interest, and let the children read on for themselves. I find the juniors rather like trying to read books above their grade and they often learn many new words in this way.

I found seniors interested in the "Funny Book" type of classics such as Lorna Doone, Uncle Tom's Cabin etc., which I'm sure would never be read in the original. I think it is our duty as teachers to fill the children's minds with as many stories and poems as she can, and awaken their interest in and enjoyment of reading that it will become a life-time habit and we hope, may lead to further self-improvement. The Education Division is building up fine libraries for these children who are learning to love to read.

Yours truly, Margaret R. Sprague.
Christie Indian Residential School,
Kakwa, British Columbia,

Dear Editor:

It was kind of you to ask us to state the reaction of the library books sent to us and how they fare under actual conditions. May I be permitted to make several suggestions?

1. Story Appeal
   A. The primary grades; The books you sent appeal very much to them. You have sent a variety of kinds for which the teachers are grateful. We hope you continue to do the same.
   B. Intermediate and senior boys have taken more to the animal stories and Mother West Wind Stories than to the others so far. Their reading tastes must be widened and increased.
   C. The intermediate and senior girls are attracted to the Teen-Age type. They prefer fiction.

2. Interest to young Indian children.
   A. Artistic appeal. They prefer colourful and illustrated books. Some of the books you sent have great artistic appeal. The reference books should have artistic appeal as the children acquire more from pictures than from reading.
   B. Some of the books have teaching value.

3. Illustrations; On the whole, the illustrations are good. In the primary books most illustrations are excellent. In the smaller grades the pictures are really quite and attract the children's eyes. Even the little ones learn more from illustrations than from the story as their background is so limited.

4. Make up or Format
   A. Utility in classroom - Yes.
   B. Binding - Poor in the smaller grades. After the children use the books a few times, it begins to come apart.
   C. Quality of paper - On the whole, good. The paper does not tear too readily and wears quite well on primary books.
   D. Cover Stock - Washable covers ideal.
   E. Size and quality of type and printing - Primary books could be larger.

5. Vocabulary; Would like it simpler, if possible, for primary grades.

6. Special features; Thanks to the Department for making it possible for the senior classrooms to obtain the more expensive Encyclopedia and the Book of Knowledge. The students really like them and do acquire much from the pictures.

A. Classics; A colourful set of well-illustrated and well-written classics for grade school children would be ideal.

B. Would there be any possibility of obtaining Cadmus books? The Cadmus publishers are specializing in children's books; making them more attractive, printing and writing them in size, quality, illustrations, printing, format, and vocabulary as ideally as they consider possible in children's books. Their prices are below the average. All their books are classified.

Address: Cadmus Books
E. M. Hale and Company
Kenosha, Wisconsin

(I am writing and asking them to send you the latest Cadmus Book List for you to peruse.)
C. We would appreciate being allowed to choose a few Catholic books each year as some excellent books are now being published by the Catholic Authors 4-Sight Edition.

Their address: Catholic Authors
1201 S. Lindbergh Blvd.
Kirkwood 22, Mo.

(I am asking the above to send you their reference books of the 4-Sight Edition of Catholic Authors for your study.)

We teachers would like to have the Department continue to supply a large variety of books. The older students are poor in reading. A large variety enables each of them to select some books they like. So far we have tried to procure most of the reference books which are excellent. In the senior grades our fiction group is small yet.

In the last few years the Department has made such rapid improvements in assisting schools in both supplies and library books that I want to voice the thanks of the other teachers and myself. We can now plan on having adequate libraries for our Indian schools. This little note of appreciation from the other end is for your encouragement to let you know that we are grateful and thankful for your efforts in building up our Indian school system.

Yours very truly,

Sister M. Loretta

Sister M. Loretta, O.S.B.

In order to insure delivery of Standard School Supplies and Text Books to the schools in time for opening of the new academic year and in order to avoid a flood of requisitions reaching this office and the Stationery office of the Department of Public Printing and Stationery we have followed a set pattern to cope with this problem in the following manner:

1. Standard requisition forms are forwarded to all the residential and day schools with the November issue of the Indian School Bulletin.

2. Residential and day schools in the Northwest Territories are requested to order their supplies by the end of December.

3. Day schools in British Columbia and Alberta are requested to order their requirements by March 31st.

4. The rest of the schools are to order theirs by May 31st.

This procedure appears to have worked out satisfactorily, however, your comments would be appreciated.

Actually we are somewhat concerned with the format of the requisition forms and would appreciate your comments.
We have three sets of requisition forms. On these requisition forms are listed books and supplies which are stocked.

We are obliged by law to secure all books and supplies through the Stationery Office of the Department of Public Printing and Stationery. They either stock our requirements or place the orders with the School Book Branches, publishers and School Book Suppliers.

The three lists are as follows (copies are attached):

(a) Standard School Supplies - Stationery
(b) Standard Text Books
(c) Supplementary to Standard School Supplies

The first two are sent out with the Indian School Bulletin to all day and residential schools. The third is not sent out at all. However, if a teacher requests items included on this third list and all concerned are satisfied that the request is justified, the request is met.

We are drafting a new format for these requisition lists and feel that some of the items listed on list (a) can be dropped and placed on list (c) without jeopardizing the operation of the schools. There may be other changes you may feel to be necessary.

It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would review these lists and let us have your comments as soon as possible as it is necessary for us to send these forms to the printers shortly.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Requisition Forms for School Supplies.

I have your letter of September 14th, file 1-1-2 (26) and appreciate your courtesy in seeking my advice in the revision of the a/m forms. My experience with Indian Schools is as yet limited but I have had considerable experience in the setting up of forms of this nature. For the sake of clarity I am giving you my suggestions under a few sub-titles.

1. Printing.
Instead of using a mimeograph or offset process have the form printed in 7 pts type. The small type with bold face titles will enable you to save paper. This can only be done, I realize, if a large quantity is to be printed.

2. Nomenclature.
I would recommend the placing of the substantive first, followed by qualifying words & Tape, adhesive paper transparent (rolls) rather than rolls Transparent adhesive Paper Tape.

3. Arrangement.
If (2) above is followed all items on the lists could be arranged alphabetically. This I consider an important point both as it affects the teacher and the clerk who fills the order. Items should be listed in alphabetical order.

4. Format and General Arrangement.
The breakdown in your other forms are apparently as follows:
   A - Standard Expendable Supplies
   B - Textbooks
   C - Supplementary Classroom Equipment

In order to expedite handling I would recommend a general rearrangement as per Appendix A.

In order to prevent waste and over or under ordering I would suggest that your order form be used as an inventory. This could be done by having two spaces beside each article headed ON HAND REQUIRED.

September 28, 1951.

With reference to the Department's request for comments on the revision of the requisition forms to be used in ordering school supplies, I would like to offer the following suggestions:

As far as possible, simplification should be made by reducing the number of forms used and the number of items which appear on the requisition forms. At the present time there are apparently five forms in all, consisting of four mimeographed sheets - Stationery, Standard Text Books, Books to be secured from the Departments of Education, and a supplementary form to Standard School Supplies - Stationery, also printed Form I.A.413. I believe this number could be reduced by omitting the supplementary form for Standard School Supplies and by the placing of certain items from this form on the regular sheet headed "Standard School Supplies - Stationery". The complexity of the last named form could be reduced by deleting certain items from this sheet. The deletions that I would suggest are as follows:

- 4214 Pencils (checking Blue)
- 4231 Erasers (Ink)
- 4271 Boxes Pen Nibs (fine)
- 4076 Pkts. Ink Powder, Red Qt.
- 1807 Blank Drawing Books #1, 6 x 9
- 1808 Blank Drawing Books #2, 9 x 12
- 1812 Loose Leaf Note Books #2933 (Gr. 9 and upwards)
- 3168 Scratch Pads #6 (8 x 10) ruled
- 1865 Pkts. Interlined Paper

Under "Exercise Books", the present scribbler "C" would be satisfactory for all purposes if it included more pages.

I would also suggest that the following items be placed on this form from the supplementary sheet to Standard School Supplies; those items listed from
Cardboard, 22 x 28, to Creped Paper, with the deletion of the Conductor's Punch and the Cardboard 11 x 14. The items listed below should also be transferred:

Indian Ink, Black
Manila Tag 9 x 12 and 18 x 24
Mathematical Sets,
Needles, sewing and raffia
Paste Par Out (one color only)
Pins No. 4
Reinforcement Rings No. 2
Sewing Cards,
Speedball Pens --- and the items on the back of the sheet, with the exception of Tracing Paper and Water Color Refills, which may be deleted.

The other items on the supplementary list are of a permanent nature and I would suggest that these could be ordered on Form I.A.413. In order that teachers may know that the Department will supply this type of equipment, I would suggest that once a year items of permanent equipment such as contained in the supplementary list be itemized in the bulletin.

If the numbers which precede the items listed on these requisition forms are not essential, I would suggest that they be deleted, since they have no meaning to the teachers.

May I also suggest that on one of the forms items be included for school requisitions, monthly report forms and pupils report forms. I have noted that teachers have in many cases omitted to requisition for these items.

I would suggest that more copies be supplied to Superintendents and to teachers than those normally attached to the bulletin. Frequently, after a change of teachers, it is found that supplementary requisitions are required and the forms attached to the bulletin have usually been used by the preceding teacher.

This office greatly appreciates the very considerable improvement that there has been in the last three years in the delivery of texts and supplies. I also appreciate the very fine selection of library books now being offered by the Department to our schools. This is particularly true concerning the primary grades and I would suggest that special attention now be given to the Intermediate and Junior High School levels.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

We also publish the Book of Knowledge and Lands and Peoples in the French edition.

Should you wish to receive further information, we will be glad to give you same upon hearing from you.

Gentlemen:

It was my privilege in the early thirties to serve for a time as a teacher in an Indian Day School on the West Coast of Vancouver Island. At that time it was customary to teach the first grade students the art of reading by means of "phase cards" and later picture posters together with an accompanying primer. Recently in Geneva, Switzerland, I learned of the difficulties that some Canadian families were having in teaching their children — who were attending elementary Swiss schools — to read English; at their request, I am writing to enquire whether it is possible to purchase from the Indian Affairs Branch a set of cards, posters and several primers of the type currently in use in the first grade.

I appreciate that this request falls a little outside the normal line of business, but I hope that either through the Department, or through some of the supply firms, it may be possible to assist these families in Switzerland.

Yours faithfully,

G. Neil Perry

Dear Les:

A letter today from Mr. Philip Phelan asks that we send you sample copies of the FAITH AND FREEDOM readers for Grades 3 to 8. This I am doing now and a duplicate set of this material is also going forward to Mr. Phelan. I understand that the FAITH AND FREEDOM readers are presently being supplied by the Department to the Catholic Indian schools in Grades 1 and 2. As you know, there are also available the NEW CORONA READERS for Grades 3 to 8 as well as the FAITH AND FREEDOM materials for these grades. As you will see when you receive the books, FAITH AND FREEDOM represents a most up-to-date basal reading programme.

The titles in the FAITH AND FREEDOM series for Grades 3, 4, and 5 are:

This is Our Town, Grade 3, Level I
This is Our Valley, Grade 3, Level II
This is Our Land, Grade 4
These are Our Stories, Grade 5

You will be pleased to see that these are Canadian editions containing material ideally suited for Catholic children in all provinces.

We are actively engaged in producing the Canadian edition of THIS IS OUR HERITAGE for Grade 6 but, in the meantime, I am sending you the original volume. The books for Grades 7 and 8 are THESE ARE OUR FREEDOMS and THESE ARE OUR HORIZONS. With these basic readers, we are sending you also the accompanying pupils' workbooks and the teachers' manuals.

The authors of the FAITH AND FREEDOM readers have recognized from the outset the need for teaching basic reading skills and, at the same time, to provide worthwhile literary content. They have achieved this dual purpose as few other basal series have. They have done this by providing entirely
separate but parallel pupils' literary readers for each of the grades from 6 to 8. The literary books for these grades are A BOOK OF VALOR, A BOOK OF FORTITUDE, and A BOOK OF FRIENDSHIP. I think you will appreciate the division in these upper grades with separate books in which students read to learn and literary books in which they read for appreciation.

If there is other information you would like about these readers, we shall be glad to supply you with it.

Re: Faith and Freedom Basic Readers

A resolution was passed at our Teachers' Convention last November recommending the use of the Faith and Freedom Readers up to Grade VIII. Since I have not examined these readers I have no comment to make on the advisability of such a change.

Would you please ask the publishers to send me for examination purposes a set of the Faith and Freedom Readers and a set of the Corona Readers so that I can give you an opinion?

Inasmuch as religion comes first, last and always in the schools operated by religious orders it is impossible to discuss the question of education objectively. Occasionally the sisters talk to me individually as teachers and express a preference for the Basic Curriculum Readers. I have noticed that in schools in the more remote areas the children often read the stories in the Corona Reader with little, if any, comprehension, because the material is beyond their grasp and too remote from their everyday life.

For a school such as the Blood R.C. school where there is a good staff of teachers and the children are in constant touch with white people the use of the Faith and Freedom Readers could be recommended. Whether they are supplied for the coming year will depend entirely upon your
stock of Corona Readers. I have had considerable experience with book supplies in my contacts with the School-Book Branch of the Department of Education. It is the practice in Alberta to use up all stock in hand before a new book is authorized. Sometimes the publisher will take stock off your hands if there is a demand for it elsewhere.

May I reserve my judgment on the quality of the Faith and Freedom Readers until I have examined them?

In the meantime I would suggest that Father Lafrance be informed that the Corona Readers will be used until the present stock is exhausted. I am not in favor of authorization of new texts by a show of hands from teachers who have not seen the books they are passing judgment on. There are scientific methods of choosing texts which cannot be ignored if we are to raise the standard of education in Indian schools and provide the kind of instruction that Indian children need.

L.G.P. Waller
Inspector of Schools.

Dear Mr. Cloutier:

This will refer to your minister's recommendation of March 24, 1952, for authority to purchase an additional Remington Rand Syncromatic Unit and key-punch, at a cost of $8,690, for use in your mechanical Accounting Section.

In considering this proposal, the Board understood that the additional unit was intended to centralize the accounting for your several paper and printing stores, as well as to introduce mechanical accounting for the Department's book stores. With respect to the book store unit, they understand that about 90% of its transactions concern the purchase, stocking, and supply of educational textbooks for the Department of Citizenship and Immigration. The Department of Resources and Development have also had some requirements in connection with their responsibility for the education of Eskimos, half-breeds and indigent persons in the Northwest Territories, but these requirements will be reduced with the formation of the Territorial Government for the Northwest Territories. The Board wondered if there were any real advantage in having your Department act as purchasing and stocking agent for these kinds of supplies which for the most part are required to meet the needs of the Department of Citizenship and Immigration. On the surface it seemed to the Board that that Department should be able to purchase these textbooks for the same price as your Department and that a great deal of accounting and paper work would be eliminated if this were done.
With respect to centralization of accounting for the other stores mentioned in your report, the Board noted the savings which were envisaged from this change in procedure. They understood, however, that there was still some unused capacity in the present equipment which might be sufficient to take care of the additional load which would be imposed on the Mechanical Accounting Section through this centralization, if the large number of items concerning book stores were eliminated.

Accordingly, the Board have asked if you would be good enough to review your book store unit in conjunction with the Department of Citizenship and Immigration to determine whether there is any advantage, economic or otherwise, in having your Department continue to act as agent for that Department's textbook requirements. If it is concluded that it would be feasible for your Department to withdraw from this field, then the Board would appreciate it if the other applications, for which the additional equipment was requested, were reviewed in the light of the available capacity on the present equipment.

A copy of this letter is being sent to the Deputy Minister for Citizenship and Immigration for his information.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum to:

Major MacKay.

Re: Book Unit -

The "Book Unit" in the Department of Public Printing and Stationery was established three years ago. It is the purpose of this Unit to handle all requisitions for school supplies and text books. Under this organization, the Queen's Printer learns the needs of this Department and other departments serviced by the Unit and stocks these requirements in a warehouse on Clarence Street.

When requisitions for school supplies and text books are received, they are first processed for stock control and billing purposes and requisitioned items are shipped to required destination. When the shipment is made the requisitioning department is billed for the goods shipped.

In the letter to Mr. Cloutier, the Treasury Board state they understand that 90% of the transactions of the Book Unit concern the purchase, stocking and supply of educational text books for this department. This information is not exactly correct as in addition to text books, school supplies and library books are handled for Indian schools by the Unit. The complete list of books and other items is as follows:

- 129 titles of text books
- 136 titles of library books
- 199 items of school supplies

In addition it must be kept in mind that books and supplies must be distributed to 66 residential schools and approximately 380 day schools throughout Canada.

High school books and some elementary school books authorized for use in individual provinces only are not kept in stock.
The present organization comprising (a) the "Book Unit" for stocking and delivery from central points of most of the requirements and (b) purchasing of miscellaneous books from the publishers has proved unsatisfactory as far as our requirements are concerned.

Should the Queen's Printer discontinue the "Book Unit" as part of his organization and hand over the handling of the school supplies and books to this department, we would be obliged to establish a central store similar to the Book Unit. This would involve:

(a) securing an amendment to the Public Printing and Stationery Act authorizing the Purchasing Agent of the Department of Citizenship and Immigration to purchase the books and other supplies

(b) obtaining adequate space, shelving, scales, etc.,

(c) securing a staff equal to that employed in the present "Book Unit",

(d) appointing two ledger-keepers to maintain stock control as this is presently done by the Pre-Paid Section of the Department of Public Printing and Stationery which is not attached to the "Book Unit" or purchase the machine suggested by the Queen's Printer,

(e) carrying during the slack period the staff required during the peak load period. At present the staff is transferred to the Stationery Branch of the Department of Public Printing and Stationery when this is feasible

(f) in order to have adequate stock on hand and permit the purchase of books, etc., in wholesale manner and thereby obtain them at the lowest prices, the procedure now followed by the Department of Public Printing and Stationery in provision of a large "revolving fund". Consequently it would be necessary to make financial arrangements similar to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery "revolving fund".
As will be noted from the above information, there are many other items of school supplies and books that have to be supplied in addition to text books.

If the Book Unit of the Department of Public Printing and Stationery is discontinued and a similar set-up is not arranged by the Department of Citizenship and Immigration, it would be necessary to place orders locally with the result that both text books and other school supplies would be purchased at retail prices rather than wholesale prices.

It would be necessary to increase the staff of the Education Division to place the large number of individual orders and to check the accounts for them. At present it is only necessary to check monthly accounts from the Department of Public Printing and Stationery.

It is likely that freight and express charges would be increased.

Conclusion:

The present system has been in operation for many years and aided by the establishment of the Book Unit in the Department of Public Printing and Stationery our distribution of text books and other school supplies to the large number of schools in our Education Division has been greatly improved and meets our requirements adequately.

Taking everything into consideration, the officials of the Education Division feel that any dislocation of the present arrangement would not be in the best interest of the service we are receiving at present for our Indian residential and day schools.

From previous paragraphs in this memorandum, it will be noted that our officials doubt that there would be any saving of funds and that there is the possibility that increased expenditures would be incurred.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. Cloutier:

Since receiving copy of the letter addressed to you by Mr. R.B. Bryce, Secretary of Treasury Board, on April 9th, regarding your request for additional accounting equipment for use in your mechanical accounting section, the suggestion that the Department of Citizenship and Immigration assume responsibility for the purchase of text-books and school material presently supplied through your book-store unit was examined carefully by officials of the Indian Affairs Branch, together with a representative of your Department. By eliminating the accounting and paper work resulting from the operation of the book-store unit, it was believed that additional equipment would not be required.

After studying the report which I have received from the Director of Indian Affairs, I do not feel that there would be any substantial saving if this Department were to take over the purchase of text-books. If a book-store unit were to be set up the present staff of the Education Division of the Indian Affairs Branch would certainly not be able to assume the extra responsibility and at the same time perform their regular duties. Additional staff would, therefore, be required to operate a book-store unit similar to the one in your Department. At least two ledger-keepers would be required to maintain stock control, and two or three extra staff to prepare and ship
orders to the 66 residential schools and 380 day schools throughout Canada. This staff would be employed only during a few months of the year when school supplies are sent out, and during the slack periods it is doubtful if they could be used on other work in the Branch. Apart from the question of staff, there would also be considerable difficulty in locating suitable space reasonably close to the Indian Affairs Branch, in which books and school materials could be properly stored.

The alternative suggestion of placing orders locally was given some thought. However, here again there would be need for additional staff who would handle the placing of the large number of individual orders with local suppliers and also the checking of numerous accounts. Under such a procedure I doubt very much if we would be able to obtain books at wholesale prices, which would add considerably to the expenditures under the Indian Education Vote.

The Indian Affairs Branch, and in particular the Education Division, has been very well satisfied with the present system, and the service which has been rendered by your book-store unit has greatly assisted the Indian education program. It is thought that if any change were to be made in the present procedure, increased expenditures on the part of the Indian Affairs Branch would result.

I am forwarding a copy of this letter to Mr. R.B. Bryce for his information.

Yours sincerely,

Laval Fortier

Regional Supervisor of
Indian Agencies,
620 Public Bldg.,
Calgary, Alta.,

With reference to your letter of May 30th regarding a book entitled "Neepawa of the North Woods" written by Mrs. Woods, we have reviewed the contents of your letter and feel that the Department is not able to help Mrs. Woods to have this book published as suggested by you.

Our requirements for library books are very small as it is our practice to purchase about 144 copies of each of the library books listed on our library list and considered to be most attractive and suitable for Indian schools. Other books listed on our library list are purchased in quantities of approximately sixty to seventy-five copies. These are, of course, books suitable for higher grade pupils.

For a publisher to consider publishing even a very inexpensive book he would require a guarantee of at least 5000 copies and if the book was more expensive the necessary guarantee would be proportionately higher.
You will readily realize that we are in no position to guarantee the purchase of 5000 copies of a book which may or may not be suitable for our Indian children in the lower grades where the largest quantity of library books is required.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

In view of this great volume of specialized business we are in a preeminent position to handle your order expeditiously and economically with a minimum of inconvenience on your part. You have merely to send us your order in the one mailing and we place your order among the publishers involved and do all the necessary importing.

Of course it is abundantly clear that the factor of greatest importance to any principal and teacher is this, that all texts must be at your school by the time term begins in September. TO ALL DEPARTMENTS

I wish to remind you again this year of the importance of ordering all of your requirements of the undermentioned items within the deadline set in the Catalogue.

Last year most departments recognized this and were quite prompt in sending in their requisitions while a few others kept sending in theirs well into December.

As you probably know, none of these items is kept in stock — even though listed in the Catalogue — but each year our orders are given to the vendors on the basis of your requisitions on hand at the deadline, and periodically thereafter on the basis of those you send in after the deadline.

Though not entirely satisfactory for provisioning and supply purposes, this is the best arrangement possible in view of the fact that new items must be bought each year, and you will therefore realize I am sure the importance to you and to us from the point of view of all-round service of ordering all of your requirements of these items before August 31st.

May we therefore look forward to receiving all of your requisitions for these items before August 31st.

You are undoubtedly well aware of the fact that it usually takes a long time (too long we feel) for service to begin on your subscriptions once you have submitted us your requisitions.

The reason for this is that the publisher wants to be paid for the subscription before he will begin service. This means that we must send him his order, wait for his invoice, and then send him his cheque. Often the invoice goes to the subscriber, and it is a long time before we get it; and once to hand, because of our volume, it takes time to process the invoice for payment.

To obtain an earlier start of service on your subscriptions while yet satisfying the publisher with regards to payment, we have thought after obtaining the approval of our Chief Treasury Officer thereon of simplifying our procedure by forwarding payment with our orders. But for us to do this we need your full cooperation as it will be necessary for you to indicate the exact price of subscriptions on your requisitions.

Are you now prepared, or would you be willing to adopt a system which would allow you to include the exact cost of each subscription on your future requisitions?

24th September, 1952.

Dear Major Davey,

Since our conversation last week at the C.E.A. Convention I have spent considerable time in combing our various lists thoroughly and have endeavoured to pick out those titles which I think might meet your particular requirements, keeping in mind:

(1) A high interest level,
(2) A low vocabulary count,
(3) A reasonable price range, and
(4) Large legible type.

Under separate cover we will forward to you within a few days two separate groups of books falling within the following categories:

(1) Straight fiction titles which we classify as trade books and on which you would be entitled to a 33-1/3% discount

(2) Educational titles, including teacher references, which in the majority of cases carry a 20% discount.

In the former group I am sending you thirty juvenile fiction titles and in the latter group there are samples of nineteen of our various "School series" as well as thirteen individual titles.

These books are being forwarded to you "no charge" and the cost of shipping is being prepaid. The covering invoices, however, will indicate the list price and discount for each title.

After you have had an opportunity to examine these books at your leisure I will be most interested in hearing which you feel might be of some value for your schools, together with an indication of what quantities you might require, which information will assist us in stock requisitions from England.

(Cont'd.)
Major R.F. Davey,
Indian Affairs Branch.

24th September, 1952.

Your comments will also give me a better idea of the exact type of books in which you are interested and will assist us in keeping you informed of new books as they are published and perhaps bringing additional titles on our current list to your attention. No doubt you will wish to retain a number of the books we are sending to you for future reference in the event you are not interested in purchasing them at the present time. By all means retain these for your Department's use with our compliments, and you may return the balance to us "collect" at your convenience.

We do hope these samples we are sending to you will give you a more comprehensive picture of the type of books our principals are publishing for children's use and we do hope you will not hesitate for a moment to let us know if there is further material you would care to examine. We are sending to you copies of several of our catalogues in which you may find other material of possible interest.

It was indeed a pleasure meeting you and I am very grateful to Mr. Neary for introducing you to me.

I expect to be in Western Canada most of October and November, but will make it a point to pay you a visit in Ottawa some time in December, or if you would prefer, I could arrange to come up to see you from Montreal on either October 6th, 7th or 8th.

Kindest personal regards,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

J.G. Myers
Educational Department

MAP S11rp CANADA Physical-Political

The new school map of Canada, printed in eight colors, is designed to show land elevations according to the internationally accepted color scheme. Shades of green indicate the lowlands, ivory the intermediate areas, and shades of brown the higher levels. The contours used are 500, 1000, 2000, 5000 and 10,000 feet. Drainage and coastlines are emphasized for greater legibility. Thereby, both the topography and the drainage pattern are brought out most effectively. The oceans are shown in three shades of blue, depths up to 600 feet, from 600 to 6000 feet, and those more than 6000 feet being differentiated. Inland waters are in light blue. Contour intervals and colors are consistent with other Denoyer-Geppert Physical-Political maps and globes.

In addition to the accurate portrayal of the physical make-up of Canada, this map includes all political data essential for classroom use. It is up to date in every respect. Cities are located by symbols and names graded according to size or population. The names of the provinces are in large, legible type, the boundaries in bold red lines. Railroads are shown by fine red lines. Also shown is the Alcan Highway.

The layout or arrangement of names on the new map will be quite different from the one illustrated. For instance, Newfoundland will be shown to extend onto the mainland, rather than confined to the island. Also, the Pacific Ocean, the Arctic Ocean, and the Atlantic Ocean will be named, the types being so arranged as to fit the space. Another point of importance is that, unlike some maps of Canada, this map includes the northernmost point of Canadian territory, also the Great Lakes in their entirety. Likewise, because of the great width of the map (72 inches) the new province of Newfoundland is located in its proper position, rather than in an inset.

OTTAWA.

Re: School Maps - Alberta.

When you were in Edmonton last December I gave you a copy of Alberta, 50" x 27", scale 1 inch = 16 miles, showing roads, surveys, towns and Indian reserves. The map was published in 1951.

There is hardly a school in my inspectorate with a map of Alberta and yet the Social Studies work requires one. I should like to have one of these maps in my classrooms.

The Alberta Department of Lands and Forests will supply these maps at $1.00 each less 20%. They can be equipped with double half rounds top and bottom for $1.60 per map; thus fitted for classroom use the total price would be $2.40.

We should require 29 for the day schools and 3 per residential school, 54 for the residential schools, a total of 83 maps.

In making this recommendation I believe that a map of this nature is an essential classroom aid to the teaching of the units on Alberta in the Social Studies course. As you know many of our teachers come from other provinces and are not as familiar with Alberta as one would wish. With the map I am proposing to supply to our schools, the teacher could find her way around the province with ease.

Would you please consider this suggestion?

L. G. P. Waller
Inspector of Schools.

With reference to your letter of December 9th regarding school maps for the Province of Alberta, please advise whether you want these maps sent to the various schools or do you want them shipped direct to your office.

As previously advised this order will have to be placed with the Department of Public Printing and Stationery and full information will be required before this is done. In the event that you wish us to arrange for the shipment of the maps to the individual schools it will be necessary for you to prepare a list of the schools where they should be sent and the quantities required in each of the residential schools listed. In your letter of May 19 you indicated that you require three maps for each of the residential schools. It is presumed you intended an average of three maps per residential school as our records indicate that the smallest school has an enrolment of thirty-five pupils and the largest approximately two hundred and forty and we do not feel that it is advisable to give each of these schools three maps.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

The department fully concurs with your comments concerning the existing Indian school register. MEMORANDUM TO SECONDARY SCHOOL PRINCIPALS

1. Behind the Headlines Pamphlets

There are several interesting pamphlets on current events published by the Canadian Institute of International Affairs. They include two of special interest at present, namely "NATO - Shield of Freedom" and "Soviet Life To-day". Within a few weeks this organization will be publishing a pamphlet entitled "Canada at the United Nations", by Edgar McInnis, which should be equally useful to teachers of current events. This pamphlet can be obtained for 15¢ per copy or 10¢ each in lots of 50 or more. A subscription of 7 issues costs $1.00.

2. Booklets for Teachers of Social Studies

Most school authorities are doubtless familiar with some of the articles from the Canadian Geographical Journal which have been issued as reprints by the Society, often in co-operation with either governmental departments or private industrial concerns. Some of these have already been sent out to the schools.

Some principals and Social Studies teachers may not, however, be familiar with the set of booklets dealing with each of the ten Canadian provinces and known as the "Provincial Geographical Aspects Booklets". These are informative and excellently illustrated pamphlets of about 30 pages each which were prepared especially for pupils of the Intermediate Division and which should prove very useful to teachers of Social Studies. The price of the set is $3.00 to members of the Society, $3.50 to non-members. There are substantial discounts for purchases in quantity. To order these booklets or to obtain further details regarding them, schools should write The Canadian Geographical Society, 36 Elgin Street, Ottawa.

3. Correction of Curriculum S.12, Mathematics for Grades XI and XII

On page 7 the paragraph, "If two sides of one triangle . . . . . has the greater contained angle," should read:

If two sides of one triangle are respectively equal to two sides of another triangle, and the angles opposite one pair of equal sides are equal, the angles opposite the other pair of equal sides are either equal or supplementary.

Please bring this correction to the attention of your teachers of Mathematics.

(over)
4. Poster Map of New Zealand

Through the courtesy of the Office of the High Commissioner for New Zealand, an excellent coloured poster map, well printed on good quality stock, has been made available. This map should prove useful for the Intermediate and Senior Grades. Individual copies may be purchased for 25¢, while lots of twenty are available for $3.00. All requests for this map should be addressed to the Official Secretary, Office of the High Commissioner for New Zealand, 107 Wurtenburg Street, Ottawa.

5. Art and Crafts Booklet

The Department of Education has prepared a booklet entitled "Art and Crafts in the Schools of Ontario" which has direct application to the teaching of art in secondary schools. This booklet may be obtained upon request from Dr. C. D. Gaiteskill, Director of Art, Department of Education, Parliament Buildings, Toronto.

6. Correspondence with French Pupils

The French Embassy in Ottawa reports that a number of French school boys and girls would like to correspond with Canadian children.

If teachers of French wish to encourage such an exchange of letters, applications, either by individuals or by groups, would be gratefully received by the "Correspondance Scolaire Internationale, Bureau Francais, Musee Pedagogique, 29 rue d'Ulm, Paris V, France."

Descriptive List of the Maps

A1 World Exploration 1492 to 1580. Further world exploration, including the voyages of Magellan and the discovery of the Pacific Ocean by Magellan and the Spanish under Elcano, is represented here along with the discovery of the New World and the first contact between Europeans and Indians. The map shows the routes of the explorers and the discoveries made by them.

A2 World Exploration 1492 to 1680. Further world exploration, including the voyages of Magellan and the discovery of the Pacific Ocean by Magellan and the Spanish under Elcano, is represented here along with the discovery of the New World and the first contact between Europeans and Indians. The map shows the routes of the explorers and the discoveries made by them.

A3 Caribbean Settlement, 1492-1543. An important but too often neglected subject is presented in this map—the opening up of the Caribbean islands to European settlement. The map shows the locations of Spanish colonial cities, and the conquests and administrative centers followed by Pizarro in his conquest of Peru.

A4 International Rivalries. Two large maps: (A) English, Dutch, French, and Spanish rivalry in the Americas from 1500 to 1750; (B) British and French colonialization to 1750. Two insets: English-Dutch competition in India and the West Indies, 1600-1763.

A5 English Colonial Grants. (A) 1580 to 1620, and (B) 1660 to 1763. The story of the grants of many colonies is effectively told in this map. New England, Virginia, and the Carolinas.

A6 Partition of America. Both North and South America. The major European possessions are shown in two maps, 1700 and 1763.

A7 Colonial Commerce and Industries. This map, consisting of two parts, shows the major exports of the colonies in 1772, and at the time of the map's printing shortly after the economic factors of our national development. More than that, it represents the economic life of the colonies as they existed just before the Revolution, accurately treated. Inset shows triangular trade routes of the Atlantic.

A8 The Revolution. The entire theatre of action, including the operations about Boston, the Saratoga campaign, the operations around New York, and the battle of Trenton.

A9 State Claims and Ratification. The first portion of this map gives the five steps of the ratification of the Constitution by the states. The second part shows the confusion of colonial charters has given rise to conflicting state claims. The boundary adjustments are clearly shown.

A10 Westward Movement. The map-sheet divided into two portions as of 1763-1843 and 1843-1861. The map shows the movement westward of the population building. The second map shows the battles of the War of 1812, naval engagements on inset map.

A11 Mexican War and Compromise of 1850. The division of the United States into free and slave states and territories is represented here along with the acquisition of new states, the Mexican War, and the Compromises of the Mexican War.

A15 Secession. Here is the map of the Southern Confederacy, showing the states which seceded, those which joined them directly, those which followed it a little later, and those which were divided by the Unionists.

A16 The Civil War. This is an excellent map of the region which constituted the theatre of operations of the Civil War. The map shows the advance of the Union forces, the number of slaves freed in each state, (B) increase or decrease in cotton production after the war, (C) number of deaths of soldiers in the armies of the South; (D) per capita wealth in the states following the war.

A17 Abolition and Reconstruction. A series of four maps showing the abolition of slavery, the number of slaves freed in each state, (B) increase or decrease in cotton production after the war, (C) number of deaths of soldiers in the armies of the South; (D) per capita wealth in the states following the war.

A18 Western Settlement and the Growth of Railroads. This map not only shows the formation of new states with the date of their admission and the Indian reservations of the period, but also shows the growth of railroads and communication by means of land grants.

A19 Lines of Transportation. The well knit network of lines intersecting within United States evidence of the remarkable development of our transportation system. Canals are shown, and the great expansion brought by a huge overland route.

A20 Resources and Conservation. This is an economic map of the United States, showing the distribution of fixed value of economic standing crops, minerals, and petroleum. Of great value for economic studies.

A21 Central United States. The map sheet is divided into two sections. The first portion gives the textile areas, and shows the location of the chief manufacturing centers of the central states. The larger map is of industrial areas, with the principal coal, iron, and steel regions.

A22 Agricultural United States. Most valuable information is given in this map. Areas of various crops bring forth the importance of the leading producing crops. Inset maps indicate dairying localities and meat packing centers, with the names of other important cities and towns.

A23 United States in the Caribbean. The interests of the United States in Panama, Nicaragua and the islands of the West Indies are shown. The map indicates the distances and distances between the chief ports of this region are also given. Insets show the chief ports and the chief cities.

A24 Greater United States. A large map which shows both shores of the Pacific and therefore portrays the relations of the United States to the Orient. The map shows all the continental and extra-continental acquisitions are indicated. It gives comparative sizes of the United States and Canada.

A25 Historic Oregon Country. Shows the routes of the American, British and Spanish explorers, also Indian trails, forts, trading posts, frontier stations, Indian villages, and the routes of Lewis and Clark. Oregon in its early history, indicating colonial possessions about 1800.

A16 Historic Pacific Northwest. This is a physically colored map of the Pacific Northwest, showing mountains, waterways, river centers, forts, political boundaries, etc.

HOW TO INSTALL PROLAC ASBESTOSLATE

All walls must be plumb and square.

All work should be well planned. When necessary, cut blackboard to fit accurately before starting installation. Score across face of sheet and break off clean.

Where possible have solid wooden background of well seasoned lumber; and when solid wooden background is not built into walls, a simple frame background can be built as follows:

Three horizontal parallel pieces of scantling with vertical pieces placed 16" apart should be attached firmly to wall.

Where longer Blackboard than standard size is desired, arrange for vertical strip in frame to suit joint.

Special flat metal joints are available making a completely smooth surface joint, which does not impair writing surface.

Where Blackboard is to be installed on solid walls, plug same 12" apart to give firm screwing surface.

Drill Blackboard and countersink holes for 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" No. 6 flat head screws \(\frac{1}{4}\)" from edge of sheet, 12" apart. Care must be taken to have holes fit plugging when installed to solid wall.

When ready to apply Blackboard, place daub of Prolac Plastic Cement, size of walnut, 8" apart on supporting back-up surface only... keep cement away from joints.

Temporary bracing must be used overnight until Prolac Plastic Cement is set. Cover bracing with soft material to avoid injury to face of Blackboard. It is often advisable where other construction work is in progress to cover Blackboard with paper to avoid injury to surface.

Always keep Blackboards in original crates until actual installation has begun.

When shipped from factory, Blackboard is liberally coated with pumice dust to prevent injury to surface in transit. Remove with clean dry eraser. Heavy flannel cloth can be used if necessary. Do not use water, soap or chemical preparations. They are injurious to all Blackboards, including natural slate.

To break in Blackboards, take flat side of chalk crayon and rub all over surface, erasing firmly. This procedure can be repeated, thereby improving writing surface immensely.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am sending you, under separate cover, the first of a little series of stories that are apparently being used with success by Mr. A. E. Smith of Oka, Que., in his work with the Indian children. We believe that there might be a need for this kind of material if done in a very inexpensive form in your schools, and we are wondering if you will do us the favour of just glancing through it and letting us know if any quantity of these books if produced, could be used in the Indian schools either now or in the future.

We shall be sending you in a day or so a copy of a new book entitled "Happy Hours in Garden, Field and Woodland" by L. A. DeWolfe, Director of Rural Education, Truro.

We are very keen on this book as it is a combination of nature study, health and art, in fact the art of living in the country. There are many illustrations in it, and as it is my understanding that Indian children are, above everyone else, children of nature, I think that you will feel that a copy of this book should be in every Indian school.

When I say this, I know that you will understand that we are not trying to "high pressure" you but merely stating that the book in our opinion is a charming piece of work. We hope that you will feel the same about it.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

J. M. DENT & SONS LTD.

C. J. Eustace

Dear Mr Phelan:

This is just a brief note to bring to your attention some of our more recent publications, which we believe might be of interest to your schools.

We believe that you have already received copies of JOURNEYS NEAR AND FAR, and HAPPY HOUSES IN GARDEN FIELD AND WOODLAND, both by Mr. L.A. DeWolfe, Director of Rural Education for Nova Scotia. These books are splendidly illustrated throughout, and inasmuch as they provide detailed accounts of the subjects with which they deal, we are hoping that you may find a place for them in your supplementary lists. HAPPY HOUSES particularly is charmingly written, and dealing as it does with all phases of nature, and the uses to which men put nature, should be of considerable practical help in Indian schools.

We are hoping to be favoured with a further order from you for both SAINTS FOR HOME & SCHOOL, and THE TEACHERS' OMNIBUS, for Grade One. We hope to issue the second Omnibus of this important series this Autumn. It will deal with Grade Two work just as fully as with the more junior work.

Professor George A. Cornish's STATISTICAL APPENDIX for Canadian School Geography, should be useful for all teachers who are using his geography texts in their schools. It is a handy work of reference, and as a matter of fact any teacher having geography lessons could not afford to be without it. Inasmuch as the price is only .30 cents a copy, let us hope that you may see fit to put a number of copies into your schools.

Finally, may we draw particular attention to our new JUNIOR NATURE & LANGUAGE WORKBOOK. This is the latest addition to this deservedly popular series, and particularly suited, in our humble estimation, to the work done in your
PHILIP PHILAN ESQ.

schools.

we have a considerable stock of TWO LITTLE INDIANS and the JOE AND MOTH WORKBOOK left, and if you are able to take a further stock of these books at this time, the order will be greatly appreciated. We are prepared to offer a special price on the charts, both mounted and unmounted. If you care to consider putting in a set of unmounted charts in all the schools using your pre-primer, we can, I think, make you a very attractive price on quantities of either the mounted or unmounted charts.

We are expecting Mr. Button back at the end of this week, for which we shall all be thankful. It is no fun carrying on without direction, although it has been a sobering experience.

I am sorry to say that we find that the A.E. Smith manuscript, entitled LOOSE LEAF STORY SYSTEM, was sent to you by registered mail on November 8th, and our records do not show that it has been returned. It is possible that our records are not all that they should be (in fact quite probable at this time of the year, just after the change from 1934 to '35 has been effected), but we should be grateful if you could have another search for this MSS made. The author is anxious to secure possession of it again.

With all best wishes, and hoping to have the pleasure of seeing you again shortly,

We are, Sincerely yours,

J.M. DEPT & SONS, Limited.

Ottawa, February 21, 1935.

Dear Mr. Eustace,

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo and have carefully noted contents of same.

On making another search, we found Mr. Smith's manuscript and I am enclosing it with this letter.

An order is being placed with the Government Stationery Office for 50 copies of Journeys Near and Far; 30 copies of Happy Hours in Garden, Field and Woodland; and, also, an additional 50 copies of Saints for Home and School.

With reference to the "Teacher's Omnibus" for Grade I, we have sent out practically all the copies that we previously obtained from you. I do not feel that it would be any use to send copies at the present time to teachers who have not received them, owing to the lateness in the academic year. You might, however, keep this in mind and write me again about the 15th of July and we will then consider placing them in the schools that have not already received them.

An order is, also, being placed with the Stationery Office for 300 copies of the Junior Nature & Language Work Book.

With reference to "Two Little Indians", I find that, since publication, we have used 7,412 copies and we have 399 in stock. We have also issued 8033 copies of the Work Book and have 382 in stock. The demand for these books at the present period of the academic year is quite small and, as the end of the fiscal year occurs next month when the Government Stationery Office takes stock, it is not likely that they will order any additional copies of these two books until early in the new fiscal year. Some time before the end of June, you will likely receive a substantial order for additional copies, in order that we may be prepared to fill requisitions in July for the books required for the academic year 1935-36.

An order will, also, be received for 100 copies of Pages from Canada's Story. We are requesting the one book edition as this is more convenient for our purposes.

I hope that Mr. Button got back and that he is feeling in good health. Please remember me kindly to him,

Yours sincerely,
